conversation:
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch. Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes. Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: You know me?
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history. You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them. We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three. So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name. You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work. Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm. In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice. You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute. Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god. The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: I've heard enough. Am I free to go?
Lord Enver Gortash: Soon. First, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate. Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: All right.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then we proceed. The patriars await. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Prepare to object.
Gale: Let's take a breath - the odds are stacked against us if we try to pick a fight now.
Player: Stop this. Gortash and Ravengard are with the Absolute!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Patriars - let it be known. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Wyll: I want to talk about what happened. About your... affliction. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.
Player: I've got no memory of my past. Could the parasite have done that?
Wyll: Seems unusual to me. Then again, we're talking about tadpoles inserted into our brains by rubber-skinned tentacle monsters. There's nothing usual about it. All the more reason to stick close, I think you'll agree. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.

Player: I didn't kill Alfira, I swear it.
Wyll: Is that so? Maybe that's fear of false accusation I hear in your voice. Or maybe it's guilt. Whichever is true, I will not stand for more innocent blood being shed in our camp. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.
Player: I've got this... bloodthirst. An urge to destroy, maim, kill.

Wyll: Anger, I understand. We've been preyed on by illithids, suffered insertion of a mind-bending worm. Bloodthirst is another matter. But perhaps not too big of one, if it's a devil or demon's flesh you're wanting to tear. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.
Player: Isobel is no more. Glory to the darkness left in her absence!
Wyll: Gods - you left Last Light for the shadows to feed on. You should be shamed for your villainy, not extolled for it. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.
Player: Isobel is no more. Glory to the darkness left in her absence!
Wyll: Gods - you left Last Light for the shadows to feed on. You should be shamed for your villainy, not extolled for it. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.
Player: Bow before me, for I have become the Slayer!

InternalNodeContext: If you "slept with" Mizora in her ROM scene, this plays the morning after.
Mizora: The pleasure of torment, the torment of pleasure. Forever marked. It's not just a contract that binds us. Can't you feel it, pet? Where my lips scorched your skin? How your soul's frozen over?
Narrator: *Your pores flood with heat and frigid water. Your parched tongue searches for the right response.*
Player: I feel it. But I'm not sure I like it.
Mizora: You may not like it. But you'll crave it in spite of yourself. A pity for you the one taste is all I'll give.
NodeContext: Cut off when an unexpected visitor interrupts
Mizora: One taste, one indulgence - but the delicious agony remains. A pity for you the one taste is all I'll give.

InternalNodeContext: Player inside the cell

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? Is that you? What curse has befallen you? No matter. The city, the future. It's done.
Player: Calm down, this cell was trivial to unlock. Getting out of here will be easy.

Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Even with the grove's numbers depleted, dealing with her there may be safer than fighting here.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.

Counsellor Florrick: Indeed. To think I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. And I can only do it with the help of the Blade. No more sulking. I know what to do. Player: I won't help you.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: All right. But this better be worth it.
Wyll: It is. I promise.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so. I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before - And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Gods, no. Have you looked at yourself? You're hideous.

Narrator: *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: What's on your mind? Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I won't harm you... I don't know what came over me.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, sister? It is good to have your assistance. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.

Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.

NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes. Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: I have no clue what you're talking about - my memories are blighted.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history. You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them. We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three. So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name. You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work. Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm. In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice. You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute. Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god. The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: I've heard enough. Am I free to go?
Lord Enver Gortash: Soon. First, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate. Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I wouldn't dream of missing it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then we proceed. The patriars await. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, by the living gods! I couldn't have asked for a finer saviour. A scorched throat, a few hairs singed off. Nothing a bit of time and fresh air can't cure. Fist Aelis, a new duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Wyll: No, it can't be. You mean, they've taken -
Counsellor Florrick: Yes, Wyll. The drow have your father.
Player: Ravengard? I know that name.
Counsellor Florrick: As well you should. He is the great champion of the Council, commander of the Flaming Fist - the binding force holding Baldur's Gate together. Without him, the city faces collapse. In fact, I fear that may have been the intention of those who abducted him. Wyll, you must hold little love for your father. But please, find him and return him to the city.
Wyll: Trust us to see it through, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: The drow took the Duke to Moonrise Towers.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: You'll need to find him without my help - I've done all I can for now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. I thought I smelled a Selnite.
Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selnite.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, by the living gods! I couldn't have asked for a finer saviour.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Pavel. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Aelis - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Aelis: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: The Absolute's cult is based at Moonrise Towers. That's where they'll have taken the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: You'll need to find him without my help - I've done all I can for now.

Wyll: I want to talk about what happened. About your... affliction. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.
Player: I've got no memory of my past. Could the parasite have done that?
Wyll: Seems unusual to me. Then again, we're talking about tadpoles inserted into our brains by rubber-skinned tentacle monsters. There's nothing usual about it. All the more reason to stick close, I think you'll agree. I was hoping you would. It's been on my mind.

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? What has become of you?
Player: So you're giving up, just like that?
Counsellor Florrick: I didn't give up. I lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: You said you wouldn't give up. I'm setting you free and holding you to it. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.

Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!

You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.

NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes. Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: Your 'favourite assassin'?
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history. You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them. We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three. So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: Ask the Emperor: Is he telling the truth?
GROUP_Emperors: It seems so.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name. You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work. Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm. In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice. You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute. Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god. The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: Very clever.
Lord Enver Gortash: More importantly, just. Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I wouldn't dream of missing it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then we proceed. The patriars await. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime. Rare is the beast that survives decapitation. Help me eliminate the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise. Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch. Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes. Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: Your 'favourite assassin'?
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history. You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them. We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three. So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: Ask the Emperor: Is he telling the truth?
GROUP_Emperors: It seems so.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name. You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work. Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm. In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice. You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute. Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god. The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: Very clever.
Lord Enver Gortash: More importantly, just. Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I have no interest in this sham of a ceremony.
Lord Enver Gortash: This is the first step towards our glory. I really must insist. You will follow me. And you will show due respect. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Father. No!
Lord Enver Gortash: The young Ravengard is with the Absolute. He means to disrupt this council.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Patriars - let it be known. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Sceleritas Fel: Master. You are the chosen one.
NodeContext: Awestruck
Sceleritas Fel: He is near... He comes for you.
NodeContext: Butler's body beginning to vibrate, and jerk strangely
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The butler levitates, held up in the air like a broken marionette on invisible strings. Daggers manifest in the air around him and plunge into his body, making a gory pincusion of him. His mutilated corpse crashes to the ground, and the blood that runs from it forms a dark pool.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. It is the butler, his hat gone, the flesh peeled back from his skull in places. Thoroughly mutilated and disfigured. His eyes burn with unholy fire - he has become an Avatar of Bhaal.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Dark Urge walks toward the pool of blood, peering down at the Avatar of Bhaal within
Bhaal Avatar: I expected the other. But you live, and her blood is returned to me. You are my Chosen. I have a gift for you, Child. You will use it to lacerate this world.
Narrator: *A gift from your god, your Father. An offering of his affection for you, or confirmation that he owns you.* *Accept Father's gift and you will reap horrors upon this world. But you will be his puppet. This is your final chance to cut your strings...*
GROUP_ORI_DU: What gift does the Lord of Murder propose?
Bhaal Avatar: My Slayer. You will grow stronger. Crueller. The prime incarnation of murder.
GROUP_ORI_DU: I refuse. I will be free of you.
Bhaal Avatar: You refuse me? You are my spawn. Your veins course with my unholy blood. Your life is mine. Accept your inheritance, or I will reclaim it.
GROUP_ORI_DU: My apologies, Father. Of course I accept.

Narrator: *Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her. Dooming the village would bring foul glory. You can almost taste it.* *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*

Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Forsake your truce. Kill her.

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? What has become of you?
InternalNodeContext: Player inside the cell
Player: So you're giving up, just like that?
Counsellor Florrick: I didn't give up. I lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: I'm breaking you out. Baldur's Gate needs you. Ravengard needs you.
Counsellor Florrick: Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.'
Wyll: Father's words.
Counsellor Florrick: Indeed. To think I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. And I can only do it with the help of the Blade. No more sulking. I know what to do. Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: Smile and take Wyll's hand.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else: Me. I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before - And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Lord Enver Gortash, the people cry your name. Will you -
Narrator: *For the briefest moment, you are one with Duke Ravengard. His mind is void - a vessel of the Absolute, awaiting command.*
Wyll: Father...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My Lord. We have a guest.
Lord Enver Gortash: Exquisite timing. Dearest patriars, but a moment. Lord Enver Gortash at your service. Lord Enver Gortash at your service. I understand congratulations are in order. Thorm's defeat hasn't gone unnoticed. You're known - for who you are, and for that Netherstone that you carry. Ah - and my old friend Karlach. It's no wonder your victory was so decisive. It's lovely to see you again, darling.
Karlach: I'm sure it is.
Lord Enver Gortash: We'll catch up once we've covered more pressing matters - Thorm's Netherstone, more to the point. I knew I'd meet Ketheric's slayer eventually, but I had no idea it was you, Karlach.
Player: Speak your piece, Gortash.
Lord Enver Gortash: You have Thorm's Netherstone. We must discuss what that means. You know, it takes all three to control the brain. Without Thorm's, it's become vexingly wilful. The quakes are a clear warning. If nobody steps in soon, it'll free itself from the authority of the crown. I expect it'll start with turning the Sword Coast's infected - you among them. That Prism of yours won't last indefinitely. Next, the Grand Design. The mind flayer empire reborn. If we're lucky, we'll become slaves. If we're unlucky, well - Not the most thrilling of prospects. But it's a fate that can be avoided if you and I come to an understanding. You may have wrought the destruction of my Iron Throne, brought my Steel Watch to its knees - but that's how I know you'd make a most formidable ally. Together we can still restore authority over the brain.
GROUP_Emperors: Of course. Gortash always did have an eye for opportunity...
Reflecting on the fact that Gortash is now proposing an alliance with the player. Hates Gortash though, so this is with an edge of resentment.
Player: I am ending this here, consequences be damned.

It's no wonder your victory was so decisive. How have you been, darling? Let's catch up later, hmm? We have more important business.

Lord Enver Gortash: You will follow me. And you will show due respect. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime. Rare is the beast that survives decapitation. Help me eliminate the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise. Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?

Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: I am going to save these lands. I- I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Lord Enver Gortash, the people cry your name. Will you -
Narrator: *For the briefest moment, you are one with Duke Ravengard. His mind is void - a vessel of the Absolute, awaiting command.*
Wyll: Father...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My Lord. We have a guest.
Lord Enver Gortash: Exquisite timing. Dearest patriars, but a moment. Lord Enver Gortash at your service. Karlach! My dear, aren't you a sight for sore eyes. How long has it been? Five years? Six? I'm delighted to see you again. Lord Enver Gortash at your service. And you are: a marvel. You've brought Ketheric to his knees and made Orin grovel. My master admires you, as I always have. For the slaughter you bring, and for the Netherstones you bear. Oh, yes - we've much to discuss. But first, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: You have so much to answer for. You think I want to watch you become an Archduke?
Lord Enver Gortash: We can discuss personal matters another time, Karlach. Believe me, you won't like what happens if you think to challenge me here, now. You will follow me. And you will show due respect. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Prepare to object.
Astarion: I know that look: the 'I'm about to do something incredibly stupid' look. There are enough of them to turn us into paste, so maybe don't? Just this once.
Player: Stop this. Gortash and Ravengard are with the Absolute!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Watchers - to arms. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first. You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless... ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?

Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, jaluk? Perhaps you are worthy to assist me. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The grove's inhabitants are weak - it's ready to fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I don't have the most trustworthy face.
Nightwarden Minthara: They're half-devil refugees... Nobody wants them. A drowning creature will cling to a blade if nothing else is offered. Be that blade. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Novice Grumm: Shit - True Soul Nere's nothing but grub-chow now. Listen up, bastards - I'm taking charge. Clean your 'nads and pack up.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: We're marching to Moonrise. And no death-curse'll be stopping us.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Wyll: Speak up. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: They will make a fine offering.
Novice Grumm: Hells yes. The General can't ignore a haul of fresh slaves.
Gale: Brittle are the foundations upon which the houses of tyrants are built. It seems I judged you to be less brittle than you really are.
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Karlach: We're not letting that happen, are we?
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: They will make a fine offering.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Thank you so - no, it can't be. Wyll, by the living gods, what's happened to you?
Player: That's my business, and no one else's.
Counsellor Florrick: I won't press for answers you won't give.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Pavel. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Ito - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Ito: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: Goblins take their prisoners to Moonrise Towers. That's where we'll find the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: You'll need to find him without my help - I've done all I can for now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. I thought I smelled a Selnite.
Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player walks toward their bedroll/sleeping area.
Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say. Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: What's happening? What are you doing to me?
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise. Let me show you.
Player: I can take it.
Mizora: I know you can, sister. You know just how much the Hells can hurt.
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen. Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war. Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Give it to me.
Narrator: *The flavour is exquisite as spiced wine, terrible as rotting offal. It does not quench your lust - it only stokes it.*

The player makes a fist, the flame extinguishes, but in doing so a new flood of sensation rushes into their core. Their back and neck arch slightly as they breath deep.
Mizora: Don't worry, pet. I won't leave 'til you're fully satisfied. Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean. Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The icy seas of Stygia.
Narrator: *You are immersed in a cold ocean blanketed by twilight. Lightning strikes you, energising and illuminating. Now that you know the thrill of its shock, you yearn for more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.
Mizora: To think how you've starved yourself up to this moment. To think how you chose the sweet over the bitter. One last choice, and starve no longer. Malbolge, the desolation. The forgotten ruins of Maladomini. Cania and its mountains of ice. Or Nessus, the seat of infernal power.
Player: Nessus, where the Hells' overlord reigns supreme.
Narrator: *You are flush with untold power. You could rip apart mountains and bring gods to their knees. This is the ultimate you: the commander of planes, the director of fate.*

The player player rotates their palms upward, and look up, basking in the arcane sensory experience.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.

Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I won't harm you... I don't know what came over me.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it. I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first. You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Sergeant Thrinn: I'll be damned. Nere's gone and kicked it. Listen, you pricks. Grab your gear and get ready to move.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Sergeant Thrinn: Death-curse be damned, we're heading to Moonrise.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Sergeant Thrinn: It's time I met the General in the flesh.
Player: What about the slaves? What happens to them?
Sergeant Thrinn: What else? They're coming with us. A gift to the General from his new faithful.
Wyll: Speak up, chief. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Good idea. They will make a fine offering.
Sergeant Thrinn: Yes. They will serve the Absolute's Chosen.
Karlach: I'm... speechless. Wow. Just... just wow.
Sergeant Thrinn: It's time I met the General in the flesh.
Player: What about the slaves? What happens to them?
Sergeant Thrinn: What else? They're coming with us. A gift to the General from his new faithful.
Karlach: Hah. Bastard can dream on. Right?
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*

Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Good idea. They will make a fine offering.

Nightwarden Minthara: I do not have time for interruptions, sister.
Narrator: *As she turns to you, her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
NodeContext: unnerved
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player sees a vision of Minthara with Orin, one of the Absolute's chosen.
InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available. Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul? Praise be, sister. Are you here to join my hunt? Her heart is more generous than mine. Join my hunt, faerie. And obey me.
Player: I'm on a hunt of my own. I'm looking for a druid named Halsin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Interesting. What do you know of this druid?
Player: I visited his grove.
Nightwarden Minthara: Perfect. This grove is the place I am seeking. Show me where it is, and we will destroy it together. There is a weapon the Absolute seeks - I'm sure those wretches have it hidden away there. We will find it, amongst the dead and the ashes.
Narrator: *Her excitement is palpable. She lingers on thoughts of victory, of unbelievers' blood spilled...* *...and of the weapon. She will seize it, in the Absolute's name.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The druids' magic protects the grove, but she may be able to break through.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch. Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes. Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: Your 'favourite assassin'?
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history. You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them. We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three. So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: Ask the Emperor: Is he telling the truth?
GROUP_Emperors: It seems so.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name. You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work. Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm. In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice. You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute. Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god. The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: I've heard enough. Am I free to go?
Lord Enver Gortash: Soon. First, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate. Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: Fine. Let's get it over with.
Lord Enver Gortash: You will follow me. And you will show due respect. Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gortash approaches Ravengard. Ravengard nods and steps forward. He holds a sword aloft - the sword of Balduran, perhaps. Gortash kneels, back to player. Everyone takes position for the Archduke ceremony.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Enver Gortash. Swearest thou, by Balduran's blade, to defend the citizens of Baldur's Gate from enemies within and without?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Swearest thou true faith and fealty to the same, by word, deed, and decree, so that none may suffer?
Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.
NodeContext: Gortadsh is still kneeling looking down.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gathered guests, grant ye consent?
Player: Prepare to object.
Gale: Let's take a breath - the odds are stacked against us if we try to pick a fight now.
Player: Stop this. Gortash and Ravengard are with the Absolute!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A traitor's words - they mean to fracture this Council!
Lord Enver Gortash: Watchers - to arms. The War of the Absolute has begun.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Lord Enver Gortash, the people cry your name. Will you -
Narrator: *For the briefest moment, you are one with Duke Ravengard. His mind is void - a vessel of the Absolute, awaiting command.*

Duke Ulder Ravengard: My Lord. We have a guest.

I'm delighted to see you again. Lord Enver Gortash at your service. Ah! My dear friend, what a brilliant child you've been to your Father. It must feel good to be the favourite. Orin must still be screaming in the Hells. Ah - and my old friend Karlach. It's no wonder your victory was so decisive. How have you been, darling? Let's catch up later, hmm? We have more important business.
Karlach: Too right.
Lord Enver Gortash: My master knows you - for who you are, and for the Netherstones that you carry. Oh, yes - we've much to discuss. But first, come and be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless... ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.
