[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Fresh air, at last. Your boldness is a blessing - I'm in your debt.
Fist Recruit Pavel: Counsellor - are you all right?!
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Pavel. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Pavel - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Ito: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: The drow took the Duke to Moonrise Towers.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: You'll need to find him without my help - I've done all I can for now.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless... ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whats inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.

Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?

We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player walks toward their bedroll/sleeping area.
Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say. Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: I'm not so sure about this, Mizora.
Mizora: A banquet lies before you. Why should you not gorge?
Player: Give in to the infernal sensations.
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise. Let me show you.
Player: I'm ready. Bring me the pleasures of the Hells.
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen. Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war. Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Gorge on the River of Blood. Relish its flavour.
Narrator: *The flavour is exquisite as spiced wine, terrible as rotting offal. It does not quench your lust - it only stokes it.*

The player makes a fist, the flame extinguishes, but in doing so a new flood of sensation rushes into their core. Their back and neck arch slightly as they breath deep.
Mizora: Don't worry, pet. I won't leave 'til you're fully satisfied. Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean. Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The roiling lava of Phlegethos.
Narrator: *Magma flows around you and into you, and the devil in you is awakened. The heat is unbearable, yet somehow not nearly enough. You crave still more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.
Mizora: To think how you've starved yourself up to this moment. To think how you chose the sweet over the bitter. One last choice, and starve no longer. Malbolge, the desolation. The forgotten ruins of Maladomini. Cania and its mountains of ice. Or Nessus, the seat of infernal power.
Player: Nessus, where the Hells' overlord reigns supreme.
Narrator: *You are flush with untold power. You could rip apart mountains and bring gods to their knees. This is the ultimate you: the commander of planes, the director of fate.*

The player player rotates their palms upward, and look up, basking in the arcane sensory experience.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. I thought I smelled a Selnite.
Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selnite.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The elder brain?
Wyll: Maybe. But I think the right answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: All right. But this better be worth it.
Wyll: It is. I promise.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else: Me. I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before - And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Gods, no. Have you looked at yourself? You're hideous.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. This Sharran exposed a traitor in your midst.
Isobel: Fair. I admit, Marcus waltzing around the place undetected bodes rather ill for our defences, doesn't it? Then again, the best defence is a good offence. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player walks toward their bedroll/sleeping area.
Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say. Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: I'm not so sure about this, Mizora.
Mizora: A banquet lies before you. Why should you not gorge?
Player: Give in to the infernal sensations.
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise. Let me show you.
Player: Sigh and brace yourself.
Mizora: What's the matter. Don't you trust me?
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen. Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war. Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Give it to me.
Narrator: *The flavour is exquisite as spiced wine, terrible as rotting offal. It does not quench your lust - it only stokes it.*

The player makes a fist, the flame extinguishes, but in doing so a new flood of sensation rushes into their core. Their back and neck arch slightly as they breath deep.
Mizora: Don't worry, pet. I won't leave 'til you're fully satisfied. Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean. Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The barren wastes of Dis.
Narrator: *Suffering. It rises from the foul ichor of the vast plains of Dis. The pain of the damned is your pleasure. Your soul cries for more, more, more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.
Mizora: To think how you've starved yourself up to this moment. To think how you chose the sweet over the bitter. One last choice, and starve no longer. Malbolge, the desolation. The forgotten ruins of Maladomini. Cania and its mountains of ice. Or Nessus, the seat of infernal power.
Player: Cania, realm of glaciers.
Narrator: *Ice. Its embrace is tighter than any you've known. It is cold, but you want colder. You want total zero.*

The player player rotates their palms upward, and look up, basking in the arcane sensory experience.
InternalNodeContext: Cannot be aliased due to VFX coloration and narration, anims resued though.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player turns and faces Mizora. She is naked, her wings spreads her wings wide.

The flame circle kicks up higher, the player and Mizora float off of the ground.

Mizora: Take me. And know the essence of the Hells.
Player: Step into Mizora's outstretched wings.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Thank you so - no, it can't be. Wyll, by the living gods, what's happened to you?
Player: Let's just say I got mixed up with the wrong crowd.
Counsellor Florrick: Yes. As Ravengard told me, where his son treads, the Hells fires are sure to burn.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Ito. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Ito - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Aelis: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: The Absolute's cult is based at Moonrise Towers. That's where they'll have taken the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: You'll need to find him without my help - I've done all I can for now.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error. And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one... ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I'll get it done.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help. The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation. We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold. I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed. We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter. He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope. You are that hope.
Player: What do you have in mind?
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage. Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?

It's all a little... odd. A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him... ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Do it - unleash your creations. But they will not protect you from me - or my righteous fury. You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
Player: Return Balthazar's mother.
Balthazar: Good. And keep your hands to yourself in future.
NodeContext: Cooling down (player has returned the jar containing his dead mother)

Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

NodeContext: a sad welcome. Rhyme is intentional and playful. Speaking softly
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: CURIOSITY KILLED ALL THE CATS IT WON'T BE SO KIND TO YOU
Narrator: *As the woman speaks, you hear a distant rattle of chains, and she winces in pain.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Ah the jailor will hear us. I shouldn't be talking to you. I must go. It's not kind to me.
Narrator: *The figure flickers and starts to dim from view. But you sense she could be convinced to return.*
Player: Wait - don't go. Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: This place must house our contract with Raphael. If Hope points the way, we might take it - and shred it.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: What is this place?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Raphael's House of Hope. But your question was hopeless. You already knew that. Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry. The House is home to many things. Most of them really want to kill you. I strongly suggest you try not to let that happen. Find your contract instead - save your soul!
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Prepare to speak in your finest stage whisper.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Where is it?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Player: Can I spin again?
Akabi: YES! DROWN ME IN COIN, AND PERHAPS YOU SHALL WIN THE ULTIMATE PRIZE.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel spins.
Narrator: *You notice a glint in Akabi's beard - as it glows, the wheel moves away from the 'jackpot'. He is cheating.*
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel lands almost on the jackpot, but then passes it - on a random prize
Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: You're cheating. I saw you rig the wheel.
Akabi: You dare speak to me as if we were equals? You are a scrap of food in my teeth. The dirt beneath my fingernails. You are nothing. I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Fine. I'll spin the wheel.
Akabi: LET US SEE IF YOU HAVE LUCK'S FAVOUR.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel spins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel lands on a random prize
Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: Nice trick rigging the wheel, but you need to work on your technique - it's obvious.
Akabi: You would accuse me, Akabi: Destroyer of Planes - of cheating? I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Forgive me - perhaps my eyes were mistaken.

Ben Golewits: The place was empty! Keep those thugs away from my family!
Arfur Gregorio: Zenovia, get these squatters out of my house now.
NodeContext: Indignant at the situation and frustrated at the lack of action from Zenovia and company
Zenovia Dawg: Arfur, sweetheart - you paid me and my boys to be caravan guards, not cattle wranglers. If you want us to get our hands dirty, it'd be our pleasure - but that'll be extra.
Player: Calm down and tell me what's going on.
Arfur Gregorio: I just want to remove these unlawful interlopers from my property!
Player: Everyone calm. Explain your disagreement, and we shall find an accord.
Arfur Gregorio: I don't see why I should be explaining myself. It's my property. They are on it - unlawfully.
Ben Golewits: Look, we needed somewhere to live. This place was empty, and it had walls. I've got children, for Tyr's sake.
Player: Mister Gregorio's right - your presence here is unlawful. It's his choice if you stay.
Arfur Gregorio: Look, time is money - and I'm losing both just standing here. Make your call, judge, before Zenovia makes it for you.
Player: I hear these sorts of houses always have basements - what do you use yours for?
Arfur Gregorio: My basement? Oh, nothing interesting! Just materials - I'm a craftsman, you see. Look, I have some very valuable components in there - I need to get that lot out before they damage something.
Player: I could help you out with that if you want.
Ben Golewits: What d'you mean by that?
Zenovia Dawg: Shhh, sweetheart - adults are talking. This is Guild business and we'll handle it - as soon as we get paid.
Arfur Gregorio: Enough of this bickering! You - what's your proposal?
NodeContext: Snapping; wants to know what's what
Player: I'll get them out of your house for free.
Arfur Gregorio: Old family motto: never trust anyone who works for free. What's in it for you?
Player: I really just quite enjoy brutalising the poor.

Zevlor: Your help at the gate was appreciated. Never thought I'd say this to a drow, but... thank you. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: Well met. Though I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm here to make sure she sees justice.
He Who Was: There is no justice for traitors - only pain. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: Peace - speak your truth. We will go from there.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

Barth: Thanks to you, that kid has my mum's locket and I got a beating.
 Got nothing to say to you. You got nothing I want.
Player: You mean this locket? How much is it worth to you?
Barth: How did you... all right, fine. I'll give you some coin for it.
Player: Forget the coin. The locket's yours. Take it.
Barth: I... I don't know what to say. I know it's stupid. It's all I have of her, is all.
NodeContext: Gruff, edge of tears.
Barth: Kind of you, friend. Here's something for your troubles.
NodeContext: Snuffling.
Barth: My mum gave me that locket on her godsdamned deathbed. The boy took the thing. I know it.
Player: Heirloom, is it? Been in your family long?
Barth: Not long, matter of fact.
Player: Read his mind.
Barth: Was in another family right up 'til mum stole it. But it's mine now - all I have.
Player: Come on, spit it out. What aren't you telling me about the locket? Not much of an heirloom then... unless there's a tale behind it, maybe?
Barth: Nothing. I'm sad, is all. Leave it alone. My mum gave me that locket on her godsdamned deathbed. The boy took the thing. I know it.
Player: Here's the locket. It's all yours.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Astarion: It's you - our little idol thief from the druids' grove!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Arabella? You should be with your parents.
Arabella: That's who I'm looking for. Mum and pops, I mean. When Zevlor - when he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm. Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll find your parents - you can count on me.
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again! The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: Live, grow up, and make your path anew by my side.
Arabella: I don't want to forget about them... I can't. To the hells with your camp, and to the hells with you.

Raphael: There. Middle-of-somewhere.
Karlach: I don't like this at all.
Player: Nice decor.
Raphael: The House of Hope. Where the tired come to rest, and the famished come to feed - lavishly.
NodeContext: He spreads his arms as he dramatically introduces this place.
Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all... ...it might just be your last.
Player: Ignore him and fill your plate.
Raphael: Not easily rattled, I see. Good. Makes the next part that much more straightforward. What's better than a devil you don't know? A devil you do.
Karlach: Fuck. A cambion.
Raphael: And so much more. Am I a friend? Potentially. An adversary? Conceivably. But a saviour? That's for certain.
Player: I never seek help from devils.
Raphael: You do not seek it, but it has found you: One skull, two tenants, and no solution in sight. I could fix it all like that.
NodeContext: He snaps his fingers on the word 'that'. As he does so, the candle flames suddenly shine unnaturally bright, bathing the scene in a hellish red glow.
Player: I'll do anything to get rid of the tadpole.

Zevlor: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: What is this place?
Zevlor: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I don't want a crumb left on that plate, girl.
NodeContext: Cheerful granny voice - you're merrily ordering Mayrina about
Mayrina: Auntie Ethel, please. One more bite and this pie is gonna come back up to say hello.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Don't make me get the wooden spoon. You're eating for two, so get to it!
NodeContext: A cheery rhythm to your voice even at the steel to your tone. You will be obeyed.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You'd best have one hells of an apology for me, petal.
Player: I'm sorry. I shouldn't have raised a hand against you.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You know, I was gonna give you a swift kick up the arse and show you the door... ...but I think you and I could have a bit of fun together.
Player: That's Mayrina? I have some bad news for her.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Keep that hole under your nose shut. Or things will get messy.
Karlach: Pfft. That hag doesn't tell us what to do.
Mayrina: What is it? What's going on?
Player: Nothing. I mistook you for someone else.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You just have one of those faces, Mayrina. So bland and forgettable. Smart move, sweetness. Now, about what you told me in the grove - your little wriggler problem. It must be an awful thing to have hanging over your head - or in it, rather. Let me take care of that for you.
Player: I'm not sure I want your help anymore.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Are you sure about that? I can tell you're almost done cooking. You know you could turn - just like that. What do you say? Want me to take care of the little bugger?
Player: Yes. Get this damn parasite out of me.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: My - I do like them eager. But know that I don't work for free. I expect payment up front... One of your pretty little peepers. I'll pluck it from your head, kiss it for luck, then back in it goes. Won't take but a moment. That is my price. Nothing more, nothing less.
Player: You have a deal.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: You are a ship without a sail, necromancer. You need allies - you need me. It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine. Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Zevlor: Your help at the gate was appreciated. Never thought I'd say this to a drow, but... thank you. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: Well met. Though I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*

Zevlor: Your help at the gate was appreciated. Never thought I'd say this to a drow, but... thank you. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: Well met. Though I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: That's sad - but it doesn't mean the druids owe you sanctuary.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: Leave.

Narrator: *Confusion crosses Zevlor's eyes as he takes you in.*
Player: I paid the price of angering the wrong devil.
Zevlor: Believe me - I understand better than most.
Narrator: *A moment passes as Zevlor contemplates Wyll's words. He then turns his attentions to you.*
Zevlor: Ah. I've already spoken to your travelling companion. Well met. I'd advise you to settle your affairs here quickly. Once the druids complete their ritual, we'll be sharing the road with goblins once again. Unless you've reconsidered speaking to them for us? Kagha might listen to you.
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.

Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: You came. Such a shame.
NodeContext: a sad welcome. Rhyme is intentional and playful. Speaking softly
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: CURIOSITY KILLED ALL THE CATS IT WON'T BE SO KIND TO YOU
Narrator: *As the woman speaks, you hear a distant rattle of chains, and she winces in pain.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Ah the jailor will hear us. I shouldn't be talking to you. I must go. It's not kind to me.
Narrator: *The figure flickers and starts to dim from view. But you sense she could be convinced to return.*
Player: Wait - don't go. Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: This place must house our contract with Raphael. If Hope points the way, we might take it - and shred it.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: Lead me to the Orphic Hammer. I will not leave without it.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Hope can help. The Hammer is here, in this House - it's...
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where will I find my contract?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE SAME PLACE YOU'LL FIND YOUR SORRY LITTLE SOUL WHEN RAPHAEL RIPS IT OUT The paper cage for your soul. Such a tiny thing, but it's one of his favourites. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me. Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him... ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: A scout is little good if they don't know what to look for. What does this relic do? I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I spoke with their ghosts. Chatty folks, all in all.
Apprentice Laridda: Ghosts? N-no. That can't be. This must be a joke.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too. Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: Fear not, gnome. I will protect you. Tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: I - all right. Go ahead, Lunkbug. Tell her.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off. We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map. If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Wyll: The trapped gnomes won't last forever. We've got to help.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Wyll: Zevlor.
Zevlor: By Dhelt's virtue, the Blade of Frontiers? What's happened, Wyll?
Wyll: I paid the price of angering the wrong devil.
Zevlor: Believe me - I understand better than most.
Narrator: *A moment passes as Zevlor contemplates Wyll's words. He then turns his attentions to you.*
Zevlor: I'd advise you to settle your affairs here quickly. Once the druids complete their ritual, we'll be sharing the road with goblins once again. Unless you've reconsidered speaking to them for us? Kagha might listen to you.
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: Leave.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the Prince of the Comet - and the githyanki people - remain forever chained.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: I'm here to kill Raphael.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: You brilliant, beautiful maniac! I'll hold him down while you trim his arteries. EXCEPT HE'S NOT HOME I'M INDISPOSED AND YOU'RE IN HELL Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry. The House is home to many things. Most of them really want to kill you. I strongly suggest you try not to let that happen. Find your contract instead - save your soul!
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Recall the hush before the roar of battle. Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where is Raphael?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: BEHIND YOU Skipping across the planes, spinning plates, making deals with dukes and devils. He's a busy man. A business-man. But not a man at all, of course. He'll be home soon, though, and you better find the Hammer before he arrives. Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where will I find my contract?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE SAME PLACE YOU'LL FIND YOUR SORRY LITTLE SOUL WHEN RAPHAEL RIPS IT OUT The paper cage for your soul. Such a tiny thing, but it's one of his favourites. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.

NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.* *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Kneel before Vlaakith, your queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Your kind is not known for trusting strangers. Quite rightly. Yet here you are. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed. You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO. I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: Fine. I will go in and kill them.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him... ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.* *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: A scout is little good if they don't know what to look for. What does this relic do? I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Eavesdrop on the conversation.
Apprentice Laridda: Lunkbug, hush. We're being watched.
Lunkbug: We're working as we can. Very hard indeed.
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Terrified of barbarian.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: Leave the True Soul to me. Now tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: Lunkbug, don't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it. A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off. We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map. If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Wyll: Thulla said to free her friends - all of them. We need to bust that wall open. And those explosives will do the trick.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Varsh Ko'kuu: You can tell Kith'rak Therezzyn that my position has not changed: the egg requires more time. Furthermore - oh.
NodeContext: You turn on 'Furthermore' expecting to see an angry guard, but you're surprised to find the player - a complete stranger.
Varsh Ko'kuu: You are not from Crche Y'llek. What are you doing here? Of course, a stranger from a strange crche may have different customs. What brings you here?
Player: I am curious about the egg you guard.
Varsh Ko'kuu: There is little to be curious about. It is taking its time hatching, nothing more.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Most caretakers would not give the child its fair chance, but I shall. There could be greatness in that shell.
Narrator: *You note that the hope in his voice is tinged with weariness. It's the voice of a man who's fought the inevitable for a long time.*
Player: Tell me the truth. Why do you really care about this one so much?
Varsh Ko'kuu: Not all that arrive late are weak. I created this entire hatchery, despite being the last of my clutch to hatch. They almost drowned me in the hatching pool. If it wasn't for the varsh of my clutch - This one deserves the same chance.
Player: This seems like an awful lot of fuss for one egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Kith'rak Therezzyn is of the same opinion. She would see it destroyed and forgotten. I'll give it a while longer, and if it doesn't hatch - it will have proven her right.
Player: Why risk its life at all? Give it to me - I'll take care of it.
Varsh Ko'kuu: You? What do you know about githyanki child-rearing? Still, the captain's due for an inspection any day now, and if she sees it here...
NodeContext: the captain will destroy his precious egg if she finds it
Varsh Ko'kuu: Tell me, what will you do with it if I entrust it to you?
Player: I'll make the best omelette you've ever tasted.
