Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will. As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you? Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Liam: P-please... please l-let me out! Th-there's no reason for this!
InternalNodeContext: Player got information, but left without promising anything.
NodeContext: Pleading, but without hope. The player talked to him before, but didn't promise to free him.
Player: Tell me where this hideout is.
Liam: No! P-please! If... if the g-goblins find out, they'll... they'll kill everyone!
Player: It's your own life you should be worrying about. Now talk.
Liam: T-to the east. P-past the ruins and the bridge. The gate's covered with ivy. But please... please don't tell the goblins!
Player: I came for the Nightsong. Where is it?
Liam: S-somewhere underneath the temple. There's a hidden p-passage. B-Brian had instructions, but... the g-goblins got him. They - they said they'd e-eat him... P-please, these shackles... I... I don't want to die!
Player: One more question: what happened to the druid?
Liam: Halsin? I... I don't know. He changed into a bear, but... I lost sight of him. I don't know if he's s-still alive. That's all I know! Please... g-get me out of here!
Player: How were you captured?
Liam: We... I was w-with a group of adventurers. We came here for an artefact. It's called th-the Nightsong. We tried to s-sneak past the goblins... ... b-but they ambushed us. I didn't think a pack of goblins could be so... so efficient.
Player: An artefact? What does it do?
Liam: I don't know. The boss didn't say. He j-just said some wizard called Lorroakan would reward us if we found it. It should be here somewhere. He said there was a hidden passage underneath the temple. The place was supposed to be abandoned, b-but when we arrived...

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Sir, I am a jack-of-all-trades and a master of many. Our meeting was not by chance - you need me. It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine. Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Zevlor: Have you spoken to Kagha?
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: Leave.

Zevlor: Your help at the gate was appreciated. Never thought I'd say this to a drow, but... thank you. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: Well met. Though I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: 'The Descent'? What is that?
Zevlor: I'm surprised you haven't heard of it. The High Overseer - our grand protector - signed a pact with devils. It dragged Elturel straight to Hell. Lucky for us, a group of adventurers found a way to bring the city back. Afterwards, people looked at us and just saw 'devilkin'. No different from the druids here, really. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: Why don't you tell me what happened?
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.

Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.

Ulma: Rech t i hathran roost.
NodeContext: REK tay ee HATH-ran ROOST
Narrator: *You recognise the funeral rites of the Gur people - the same monster hunters you met in the hag's swamp. Their leader is burning the possessions of those who have fallen.*
Ulma: Im orak ne tay. Krasin ne trah!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ulma pauses for a moment, staring at the fire in contemplation before she turns and walks over to the player.
Ulma: So, the impossible spawn walks among us in the blazing sun. We have been looking for you.
Astarion: I noticed. It didn't end well for the hunter I met in the swamp.
Ulma: You would be wise not to dredge up the past, spawn. The last time you came to our camp, you stole our children. Our future. When we sent Gandrel after you, we wanted to interrogate you. To discover how to save our children and then destroy you. But things have changed. You have changed. Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: What does it matter to you?
Ulma: It matters because you are the last hope to rescue our little ones from Cazador Szarr. We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended. But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining. He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: And if I decline to help?
Ulma: Then we can all see what you really are. At best, a coward. At worst, a monster. So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Attack her.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not. 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm. Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll find your parents - you can count on me.
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again! The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: Their bodies fester, pumped full enough of quack serums, swelling organs ready to burst.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Hello, sweetness.
Player: What happened to Mayrina? Did you do something to her?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I don't like busybodies.
Player: Do you treat all your guests so poorly?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Hm?
NodeContext: You're shocked the player corrected you. Your expression should be neutral, tense moment as we're not sure how you'll react
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That wriggler in your head isn't going to get its damn self out, is it? That wriggler swimming in your brain juice is a bit of an inconvenience, isn't it?
Player: Something isn't right. That woman - why is she with you?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Busybodies are not appreciated around here.
Astarion: Let's not make trouble for some stranger. We have our own problems.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll talk about your wriggler - and that's it. Last warning.
Player: Fine. Can you remove the parasite?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Quicker than you can say 'Yes, Auntie.' What do you say? Want me to take care of the little bugger?
Player: Such things are rarely done for free. What's the real bargain here?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You're a sharp one. I am proposing a deal, but it's different from your little pact. You see, I prefer personal things. One of your pretty little peepers. I'll pluck it from your head, kiss it for luck, then back in it goes. Won't take but a moment. That is my price. Nothing more, nothing less.
Player: You have a deal.

Zevlor: I'd advise you to settle your affairs here quickly. Once the druids complete their ritual, we'll be sharing the road with goblins once again. Unless you've reconsidered speaking to them for us? Kagha might listen to you.
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: Leave.

Skickpit: What now?
Player: Take the lift to the surface.
Skickpit: Shit - up there? Forget it. I hear the land's cursed clear to Moonrise.
Player: The curse is cleared. You'll be perfectly safe.
Skickpit: Cleared - just like that, huh? Well I'm not taking the chance. Any other ideas? What now?
Player: Take the lift to the surface.

Barth: Watch your bags, huh? Learn from my mistakes. I'll say this for those devils: they know how to throw a punch. My mum gave me that locket on her godsdamned deathbed. The boy took the thing. I know it.
Player: You mean this locket? How much is it worth to you?
Barth: How did you... all right, fine. I'll give you some coin for it.
Player: Read his mind.
Barth: It's the last thing of mum's I have... it's worth everything to me. What're you waiting for? I told you I'd give you some coin. Hand it over!
Player: Forget the coin. The locket's yours. Take it.
Barth: I... I don't know what to say. I know it's stupid. It's all I have of her, is all.
NodeContext: Gruff, edge of tears.
Barth: Kind of you, friend. Here's something for your troubles.
NodeContext: Snuffling.
Barth: My mum gave me that locket on her godsdamned deathbed. The boy took the thing. I know it.
Player: Heirloom, is it? Been in your family long?
Barth: Not long, matter of fact.
Player: Not much of an heirloom then... unless there's a tale behind it, maybe?

Narrator: *An ornate mace hovers before you, suspended in a shaft of brilliant light.* *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.* *This mace certainly has a very unusual design.*
Player: Reach into the light and take the mace.
Shadowheart: Not one to heed warning then? This could end very badly.

Gale: Are you quite sure that's wise?
Wyll: Leave it be. Not every glowing light is an invitation take what's inside it.
Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.* *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.* *Taking this mace would surely lead to something quite disastrous.* *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Take the mace anyway - what's the worst that could happen?

Zevlor: You're the one who knocked my jaw out of joint.
NodeContext: Player knocked Zevlor out to defuse an earlier confrontation - he's a bit aggrieved
Zevlor: And yet you walk in here like it's your domain. Typical drow arrogance. Lucky for you, you seem to have spooked Aradin and his trash into leaving. Raise your hand to one of us again, however, and every tiefling in this encampment will fall on you like a tide.
Player: Loose tongue, bruised jaw - perhaps they're related?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. And you'll survive as long as you keep your hands to yourself. You helped us fight those goblins. Who are you?
Player: Just passing through.
Zevlor: Right. Best not to stop here. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Do it - unleash your creations. But they will not protect you from me - or my righteous fury. You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
Player: Return Balthazar's mother.
Balthazar: Good. And keep your hands to yourself in future.
NodeContext: Cooling down (player has returned the jar containing his dead mother)
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Liam: N-no! Please! D-don't hurt me!
InternalNodeContext: Main dialogue branch, happens if the goblins aren't there and the player didn't torture the adventurer.
NodeContext: The adventurer has just been tortured by goblins. He's extremely scared of everyone.
Player: That depends on the answers you give me.
Liam: I c-can't tell you where the grove is, please. If they find out, they'll... they'll kill everyone!
Player: It's your own life you should be worrying about. Now talk.
Liam: T-to the east. P-past the ruins and the bridge. The gate's covered with ivy. But please... please don't tell the goblins!
Player: That's my concern now. How did you end up here?
Liam: We... I was w-with a group of adventurers. We came here for an artefact. It's called th-the Nightsong. We tried to s-sneak past the goblins... ... b-but they ambushed us. I didn't think a pack of goblins could be so... so efficient.
Player: An artefact? What does it do?
Liam: I don't know. The boss didn't say. He j-just said some wizard called Lorroakan would reward us if we found it. It should be here somewhere. He said there was a hidden passage underneath the temple. The place was supposed to be abandoned, b-but when we arrived...
NodeContext: he trails off, lost in the memory of the goblins attacking and overpowering them.
Player: Go on. Where can I find the Nightsong?
Liam: B-Brian had instructions, but... the g-goblins got him. They - they said they'd e-eat him... P-please, these shackles... I... I don't want to die!
Player: One more question: what happened to the druid?
Liam: Halsin? I... I don't know. He changed into a bear, but... I lost sight of him. I don't know if he's s-still alive. That's all I know! Please... g-get me out of here!
Player: How were you captured?
Liam: We... I was w-with a group of adventurers. We came here for an artefact. It's called th-the Nightsong. We tried to s-sneak past the goblins... ... b-but they ambushed us. I didn't think a pack of goblins could be so... so efficient.
Player: The druid Halsin was with you. Where is he now?
Liam: I... I don't know. He changed into a bear, but... I lost sight of him. I don't know if he's s-still alive.
Player: You came looking for the Nightsong, didn't you?
Liam: Y-yes, it should be here somewhere. They said there was a hidden passage underneath this temple. The place was supposed to be abandoned, b-but when we arrived...

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Eavesdrop on the conversation.
Lunkbug: We'll never get through. We need that smokepowder.
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Philomeen's gone. And if she's smart, she won't be coming back.
NodeContext: Whispered
Lunkbug: Tell the sergeant where she went - Beldron's still trapped with that maniac Nere!
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I spoke with their ghosts. Chatty folks, all in all.
Apprentice Laridda: Ghosts? N-no. That can't be. This must be a joke.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too. Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: To protect the innocent is my call. Trust me. I won't fail you.
Apprentice Laridda: I - all right. Go ahead, Lunkbug. Tell her.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off. We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map. If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Astarion: Well, some explosives would certainly help us free Thulla's friends. They might even survive the blast.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Arabella? You should be with your parents.
Arabella: That's who I'm looking for. Mum and pops, I mean. When Zevlor - when he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*

Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: You're going to get yourself killed. I'll find them, all right?

Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe. It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power. Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together. But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it? In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.
Nightwarden Minthara: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold. We may fail, but we must try. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us. You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: You may be right. I'll keep an open mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: That is all I ask. And remember, I know when your mind is closed. We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose. There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain. When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Because I'll rip your tongue out, shove it down your throat, then stomp on your 'creations' until they are dirt beneath my feet. You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her. I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things. I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will. As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Havkelaag: A series of moral imperatives bestowed by the great dragon-deity Bahamut. In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.* *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Wave politely.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player waves politely at Vlaakith.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I expected little of istik education, but here we kneel before our queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Lae'zel: Vlaakith has spoken. You have listened. This is the way.
Vlaakith: My child. You walk on the path of ascension. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

Sazza: Wotcher messin' with my cage for? It's too late to make friends, worgmeat. My tribe's comin'. They're gonna burn this pretty place for the glory of the Absolute and 'ang ya by yer guts.

Wyll: I'd sooner swig a flask of acid than anything a goblin cooks up.
Player: Nice story. Buy it for a copper in a tavern nearby?
Sazza: It's the truth - I swear on your mother's grave. Get me out of 'ere and I'll tell you where to find 'er. Deal?
Player: Deal. I'll get you out of there.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me. She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable. If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it. She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together. But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it? In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.
Nightwarden Minthara: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold. We may fail, but we must try. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory. You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: Maybe I'll change your mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try. We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose. There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain. When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Arabella: I don't see any - wait. Here they come! Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not. 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*

Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Havkelaag: A series of moral imperatives bestowed by the great dragon-deity Bahamut. In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed. You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: So you need my help - what would I have to do? What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Nere: Finally. Worthless slaves. Your incompetence has been my ruin.
NodeContext: Intense but quietly so. ZHIL loo-NIN! Rising, seething anger. Only the last word should be louder.
Player: Stop! No more innocents will die today, Nere.
Nere: You care for the weak, True Soul. Most curious.
NodeContext: Quiet.
Player: I came on the myconid sovereign's behalf. It demands revenge.
Nere: You heed an overgrown toadstool, yet defy a True Soul? A test - yes, you must be. The Absolute bade you to try Nere's faith. Thrinn. Carve out their heart and serve it to the roth. If they are indeed a True Soul, let the Absolute save them.
Player: I'll offer up your guts, ingrates.
Nere: You are a traitor.
Elder Brithvar: Shut your shitholes, both of yeh. You owe my crew a tenday's worth o' coin, Nere - and it's time you shell out.
Nere: Direct your blade at the heretic, duergar. You shall have your coin.
Elder Brithvar: Damn right I'll have it - straight off your rotted corpse.
Nere: Nere is not without mercy, True Soul. The rat has given you a chance to earn my favour. Strike him down. Prove your faith.
Player: Side with Nere.

Player: The pain stops when you answer my questions.
Liam: P-please! You kn-know where the grove is! Th-there's nothing I can tell you... please, let me go!

Liam: I don't know. The boss didn't say. He j-just said some wizard called Lorroakan would reward us if we found it. It should be here somewhere. He said there was a hidden passage underneath the temple. The place was supposed to be abandoned, b-but when we arrived...

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Astarion: Good morning. How do you feel?
Player: I'm fine, I just feel a little woozy.
Astarion: It'll pass. Just be glad I'm not a 'true' vampire. A bite from them and you might wake up as a vampire spawn, like my good self. All of a vampire's hunger, but few of their powers. Of course, I can't summon wolves or turn to mist like a 'true' vampire. Being a spawn has its drawbacks.
Player: Is that how you can stand in the sun? Because you're not a 'true' vampire?
Astarion: Oh no, I should be cinders in this light. I hadn't seen the sun for two hundred years before we crashed here. Someone - or something - wants me alive. They've changed the rules. Standing in the sun, wading through a river, wandering into homes without an invitation - they're all perfectly mundane activities now. As for my other quirks - well, we can figure those out in time.
Player: If I can help, just ask. We're in this together.
Astarion: Oh you're such a sweetheart. I'm just glad you're being sensible about these revelations. I was worried people might turn up with torches and pitchforks. Although there's still time.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.

Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: What are the properties of this relic, magical or otherwise? So I can be of better assistance, of course. I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Wyll: Yes. But first, a question. If your home were under siege, what would you sacrifice to save it?
Player: I'd give my life if it meant keeping the residents safe.
Wyll: As would I - and more. I was seventeen. Father - Ulder Ravengard - had just been named a Grand Duke, and was called away to Elturel to help settle a dispute. Yes - my father is a Grand Duke of Baldur's Gate, and I am his only son. That's when the Cult of the Dragon made its move.
Narrator: *The Cult of the Dragon - a fractured religion. Some believers hold that undead dragons will inherit the world.* *Others worship your goddess, the dragon Tiamat, and intend to summon her to Faern.* *Others worship the dragon goddess Tiamat and intend to summon her to Faern.*
Player: What's the Cult of the Dragon? I've never heard of them.
Wyll: A religion devoted to conjuring the most evil of goddesses, the dragon Tiamat. A tenday after father left, I heard a whisper as I slept. 'Dusthawk Hill. The Queen of Chaos awakens. Go alone.' I grabbed a rapier and set out. There wasn't a cloud in the sky, yet not a single star was shining. There they were, gathered at the foot of the Hill.
Narrator: *Your head tingles. Wyll wants to show you what happened.*
Player: Allow Wyll to share his memory with you.
Narrator: *In the looming shadow of the mount, five groups of five figures each encircle a lofty totem.* *Atop each totem, a dragon's head is carved, and a massive orb held in its mouth. The cultists chant, first softly, then crying to the starless sky.* *There is a crack of thunder, a gust of wind - and a dragon's white head appears in the storm.* *As the maelstrom howls, Mizora's lips press to your ear. 'She will destroy Baldur's Gate. Grant me your soul - and I will give you the power to save it', she whispers.*
Wyll: She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: Sacrificing your soul to save the city was a brave thing to do.

I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Your parents are test-fodder stuffed full of needles, little orphan.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.

Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: Of course. You can stay in my camp.

Nere: Finally. Worthless slaves. Your incompetence has been my ruin.
NodeContext: Intense but quietly so. ZHIL loo-NIN! Rising, seething anger. Only the last word should be louder.
Player: Touch another innocent and I'll take your head, Nere. Stop! No more innocents will die today, Nere.
Nere: You care for the weak, True Soul. Most curious.
NodeContext: Quiet.
Player: I act on orders of the Absolute.
Nere: So you say. And yet the Absolute demands that I cull them. A test - yes, you must be. The Absolute bade you to try Nere's faith. Thrinn. Carve out their heart and serve it to the roth. If they are indeed a True Soul, let the Absolute save them.
Player: That's your cue, Brithvar. It's time you got paid.
Elder Brithvar: Damn right it's time. You owe my crew a tenday's worth o' coin, Nere - and the reckoning's come.
Nere: Nere is not without mercy, True Soul. The rat has given you a chance to earn my favour. Strike him down. Prove your faith.
Player: Side with Brithvar and the rebels.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: I have read your treatise. Initiate the final lesson, or die by my hand.
Malus Thorm: The final lesson. Yes. For to teach absence, one must become absent. I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dribbles stands atop the stage, a big smile on his face. Group of children crowded at the front.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Buddy the dog is my very best friend. Do you know why?
Quinton: Why?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Because with him, anything is paw-sible. Wa-hey!
NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?
Lae'zel: Can we not find a more pleasant amusement? Gouging out our own eyeballs, perhaps?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Did you hear about the scarecrow who lost a fight?
Player: What a corny joke.

NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?

NodeContext: Puts his hands to his eyes and dramatically scans the crowd - suddenly locks eyes with the player.

GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Come now, don't be a Cowardly Connie. Perhaps you need a little encouragement?
NodeContext: looks at crowd expectantly, raising his hands to 'give it up' for the player.
