[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry? Well - it won't stain this beautiful city with its abominations - not anymore. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you. But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Wulbren, enough. The Gondians are no more - I am all that is left. You've won. Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace. Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: He's right. It's over.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check. You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes. I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around. Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention. I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: You are outnumbered and outmatched, Wulbren. Retreat - now. LEAVE, LITTLE WULBREN. OR DIE.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Abhorrent?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I am working against Bhaal - I got a hold of the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: Father has shown me visions - the Temple of Bhaal lurks somewhere in the city.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: So it's all happening again... just like in Sarevok's time... A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: You should raise this with your superiors, immediately.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Don't you think I've tried? They won't listen. You're lucky you met me - most of the Fist wouldn't have believed you were a Bhaalspawn. Think it's Baldurian superstition. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You really are a godsend. But - one more thing... There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: The Flaming Fist should be protecting everyone - not just Upper City folk.

Narrator: *Approaching the cells, you're met by hollow faces and eyes reluctant to meet your gaze. There's an almost physical stink of decay and neglect.*
Sebastian: You. I know you.
Narrator: *The last time you heard this voice, it was singing drunkenly, whispering sweetly, then sighing with pleasure.* *One of your conquests, claimed for Cazador. He should have been consumed long ago.*
Astarion: You're mistaken. I have no idea who you are.
Sebastian: LIAR. You whispered my name, over and over. It sounded like a lyric on your tongue. I want to hear you say it again. Say my name.
Narrator: *He looks at you expectantly, his hollow eyes boring into yours.*
Astarion: Sebastian.
Sebastian: You still make it sound so beautiful. You were my first. And my last.
Astarion: You should be dead. Why didn't Cazador feed on you?
Sebastian: He made me a spawn. Left me here to rot. But I can't rot - I can't die. How long has it been?
Astarion: I'm here to stop the Black Mass - to kill Cazador.
Sebastian: Kill that monster? You can't. It's impossible.
Astarion: I've done the impossible before.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Of course I noticed. It was no party without you.
Wyll: Really? I'm honoured. In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night. I'm a devil. I love the people from the grove, but I unsettle them deep down. As I seem to unsettle everyone nowadays. You don't want a devil at your party. Horns this sharp will pop the balloons, you see. And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.
Player: Sorry it has you feeling rough tonight.
Wyll: Ah, I'll be fine. Seeing you has cheered me more than you can know. But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: You must have stumbled out here by complete accident. Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: You're halfway right.
Wyll: Oh! I will safeguard my undergarments with care. Let me think... Why are you really here? You were hoping for some peace and quiet out in the forest, and I have ruined your night entirely. Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Keep trying!
Wyll: It's a long shot, but - maybe you've grown fond of me. Gods know I've grown fond of you.
Player: Was I that obvious?

Oyster Boy Dringo: Uhh, hi.
Player: That woman seems like a harsh taskmaster.
Oyster Boy Dringo: She's mean. But dad says she'll toughen me up. That's why I need to work hard in the kennels every day. To get tough.
Angry Mar'hyah: Dringo! Get back to work! And you - what do you want? This is a private yard. You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods. Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.
Player: Hello.
Angry Mar'hyah: Hello. What do you want? You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods. Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.
Player: Sorry.
Angry Mar'hyah: It's fine. I have a very robust sense of humour. What do you want? You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Whistle for Scratch.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dog approaches player
Oyster Boy Dringo: Scratch! It's good to see you boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut up, Dringo. And get back to work! And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy. This dog is property of Sword Coast Couriers. I'll take him off your hands now.
Player: You shouldn't raise your hand to him like that.
Angry Mar'hyah: I can do whatever I please - he's my dog. Now get out - this is a private yard.
Player: This noble beast has tasted true freedom - he will never be brought to heel again.
Angry Mar'hyah: I'm not surprised. Gomwick always indulged him. And he's got a spark in his eye I don't like - looks lively. Take the useless mutt if you're so inclined. I'll have nothing more to do with him.
Oyster Boy Dringo: It's not just Scratch. She's always hurting the dogs.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut your mouth, Dringo. Last warning.
Player: I hear Lord Gortash abhors animal abuse. Perhaps I should report you to him.
Angry Mar'hyah: Fine. You think you can do a better job without me - be my guest. They're a useless bunch of mongrels. You're welcome to them!

Wyll: 'Unhappy' doesn't begin to describe it. He returned to an unsuspecting city and a wayward son with a smirking devil at his side. I tried to tell him the truth, but my mouth couldn't form the words. I led him to the battlefield, but Mizora had swept it clean. I showed him my stone eye - but he only turned away. After, he said only one word: 'Go.' So I did. She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: Surely Mizora doesn't care about Baldur's Gate. Why would she want to save it?
Wyll: She didn't - she came on order of her mistress Zariel.
Karlach: She never stops, does she. Not for a second.
Wyll: Tiamat made a play for power. Zariel had other plans. That's the most Mizora's ever said - all that mattered was that she got her prize: Another pet added to her warlock menagerie. She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: It was brave, what you did for the city.
Wyll: She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: Is that how you lost your eye - in the battle with the Cult of the Dragon?
Wyll: It is. The one scar I ever bore of it. You were right, of course - the new eye is a sending stone, courtesy of Mizora. She uses it to track my location and call from a distance. I could flee to the Spine of the World or the depths of the Lowerdark, and still never shake her. She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.

Narrator: *The device is strange, made of taut flesh and pockmarked metal. It waits for something.*
Lae'zel: The zaith'isk. Vlaakith's purity, distilled. My duty. My right.
Player: Stand back. I'm going first.
Lae'zel: I will not. I gave you my might. You will respect my charge.
Player: Very well. Step forward and be cleansed.
Lae'zel: Praise Vlaakith, let it be done.
Ghustil Stornugoss: You are infected too, child? Sit, ra'stil. Let the zaith'isk end your suffering.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The 'head' part of the machine descends and the jaws clamp around the Laezel's head, neck, shoulders.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.
Ghustil Stornugoss: You must focus on the parasite at all times. The zaith'isk will do the rest.
NodeContext: Instructive - this is very important
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A psychic forcefield emerges, 'locking in' Lae'zel's head to the Zaith'isk.
Narrator: *An unseen blade cleaves your mind in two. Impossible pain sears your bones and body in concert with Lae'zel's.*
Lae'zel: Ngh! Vlaakith tavki na'zin. Vlaakith tavki na'zin!
Laezel's face is a picture of discomfort. - Reuse |

Ghustil Stornugoss: Yes, child. Speak the Tla'ket. Meditate on its verses.
Narrator: *You feel Lae'zel's mind rip and rupture. Is this purification? Is this the cure?*
Player: Wait and watch.

Narrator: *You share in Lae'zel's agony. Every cell within her skull bursts into a constellation of fragments, sorted and reassembled. Lae'zel will die if she remains.*
Ghustil Stornugoss: Yes, child. Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. Call to your queen!
Lae'zel: My Queen, hear me!
Shadowheart: That thing's killing her!
Narrator: *Your vision narrows. You sense myriad spectres of githyanki past. This is their fate. This is their anguish.*
Player: I've seen the truth, Lae'zel. This device doesn't cure - it kills.
Lae'zel: WHAT? Tsk'va!

Narrator: *There is a fleeting connection. Your parasite communes with his, then falls quiet.*
Wyll: Father...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My dearest boy. The Hells have touched you. But you've come to me - just as Gortash said you would. A True Soul no less. Father and son, unstoppable generals. You and your allies will usher in a new dawn. Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web. Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus. She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
Narrator: *Within Ravengard's memories, you find Counsellor Florrick. She is confined in a cell, right here in Wyrm's Rock.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready? Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: Gortash is a tyrant. This 'new dawn' is a lie.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Why do you say this? Only the shadows would name the sun a tyrant. Faern suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.
Narrator: *Tyr's fury glows within you. Despite Ravengard's words, the Lord of Justice has remained loyal to you, as you have to him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But Baldur's Gate will soon burn bright. A beacon to light the heavens. And it will be Gortash who ignites the final spark. Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: My father, my hero. I'll save you from the Absolute's thrall.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: What is a hero, if not an actor for the greater good? Faern suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.
Narrator: *Tyr's fury glows within you. Despite Ravengard's words, the Lord of Justice has remained loyal to you, as you have to him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But Baldur's Gate will soon burn bright. A beacon to light the heavens. Gortash and I will ignite the final spark. And that, True Soul, is the greatest of goods. Have you come to behold the new dawn?

Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crche?*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. Who are you?
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Don't worry - I'm not here to judge.
Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: Depends on how you define 'good'.
Ptaris: There is only one way. The Ptarian code. Do you follow it? The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Ptaris: It is honour. Justice. The true form of goodness we all must live by, decreed by Bahamut himself. You are not capable of following its teachings. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.

Player: I gave you what my patron gave me - a chance at something more.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand. Father saved me. I was a nasty, evil thing, but his treatments made me good. I - I'm cured.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: What? I've got a duke's murder to solve, and not a lot of time to do it. Have you found something?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unfortunate?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I am working against Bhaal - I got a hold of the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: I don't know much. I only just found out I was a Bhaalspawn in a vision.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You've had a busy tenday. I can't even imagine. Well, I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: You said Sarevok led the cultists a century ago - he can't still be alive, can he?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Stranger things have come back to haunt this city. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faern couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am no student, I seek knowledge of the curse. It is a blight on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.

 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.

Player: The Flaming Fist should be protecting everyone - not just Upper City folk.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I spoke with their ghosts. Chatty folks, all in all.
Apprentice Laridda: Ghosts? N-no. That can't be. This must be a joke.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too. Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: A terrible situation. I'm sure you'll pay handsomely if I help.
Lunkbug: Found it in the ruins. It's all I've got. Please, just listen. A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off. We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map. If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Astarion: High-powered explosives do sound fun, but must we waste them saving lives?
Player: I'll do what I can.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!

Shadowheart: Oh, come on now - it happens to the best of us, from time to time.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.

Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)

Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh bollocks - I told those idiots not to let anyone through. YOU. Name, rank, and reason for interrupting an active crime scene. For your sake, the last one better be bloody good.
Player: Are you Devella? Valeria sent me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: To fetch her another bottle of mead, no doubt. Yes, I'm Devella, the unfortunate colleague. Unless you've got useful information, leave me to my work. Duke Stelmane's dead - and I've got to find who killed her.
Player: I know more about Bhaal than anyone you'll find. You don't want to send me away.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unlikely?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I am working against Bhaal - I got a hold of the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: I was hoping you could tell me more.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Most of what I know is based on reading into Sarevok's history. I'm sure it's nothing next to your personal experience, but I'll share what I have. A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be another Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faern couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You really are a godsend. But - one more thing... There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Are you all right?
Wyll: Oh, I'm deeply proud of you. A touch less so of myself. In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night. We've saved the grove, and everyone hails us as heroes. For you, it's as clear as cool water you have that heroism within you. But Karlach is dead, and Gods know how many other of my victims were people like her. I shouldn't be celebrated tonight. That's why I left.
Player: Don't complain. We're all still alive, aren't we?
Wyll: You're safe another day. Really, that should be enough. But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: Clearly Mol has put you up to stealing my britches so you can turn them into a flag for her gang. Not that I'd necessarily object. Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: Nope. Guess again.
Wyll: Let me think... Why are you really here? You must be Volo in disguise, out here to harangue me for some tales of the Frontiers. What a cruel disguise! My nerves started hammering the second I thought they were the one looking for me. Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Because I like you. And I want to know you better.
Wyll: Then we share a similar affliction. For I've grown fond of you too. Though I can't say I've earned the honour. I haven't even managed to kill one measly devil. I'm hardly a prime catch. The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.
Player: Maybe a kiss would prove my affections.
Wyll: *Sigh.* You drive a hard bargain. But just the one.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Wyll stoops to share a quick kiss.
Wyll: I - well, then. Erm, you've got a party to get back to. After all, tonight is about you. There will be another time for us.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you. I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares. Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go. To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us. The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: Is the ghaik incursion not more important?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You mean the Grand Design? The restoration of the Illithid Empire? Why, it is of the utmost importance. But the weapon is the solution. I have heard it directly from Queen Vlaakith herself. It is how we will stop the mind flayers before they destroy us all. Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va. The weapon. Now.
Player: I thought the Grand Design was a ghaik philosophy, not an actual plan.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The Grand Design is what all ghaik seek. The restoration of the Illithid Empire, which spanned the entirety of the multiverse. For centuries, their elder brains sought to bring back their dominion. Every plot they hatched, we stopped. But now, they are close to succeeding. Never before could they pause ceremorphosis. Never before could they let the infection spread undetected. Imagine that everywhere. Wants, needs, choice - all would cease to be. Everything rendered unto the ghaik. So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: You can't trust him, Lae'zel. Follow my lead. I will choose the right path.
Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth. Choose. Your path is mine to follow.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: You've never seen another githyanki before?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that! I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: What did they do that was so terrible?
Ptaris: They did not live up to father's code. Even he did not follow it correctly. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: No one code can define goodness. It's impossible.
Ptaris: Only a bad person would say that. And that's what you are. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I gave you what my patron gave me - a chance at something more.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand. Father saved me. I was a nasty, evil thing, but his treatments made me good. I - I'm cured.

Wyll: Yes. But first, a question. If your home were under siege, what would you sacrifice to save it?
Player: I'd give my life if it meant keeping the residents safe.
Wyll: As would I - and more. I was seventeen. Father - Ulder Ravengard - had just been named a Grand Duke, and was called away to Elturel to help settle a dispute. Yes - my father is a Grand Duke of Baldur's Gate, and I am his only son. That's when the Cult of the Dragon made its move.
Narrator: *The Cult of the Dragon - a fractured religion. Some believers hold that undead dragons will inherit the world.* *Others worship the dragon goddess Tiamat and intend to summon her to Faern.*
Player: Nod and let Wyll continue his story.
Wyll: A tenday after father left, I heard a whisper as I slept. 'Dusthawk Hill. The Queen of Chaos awakens. Go alone.' I grabbed a rapier and set out. There wasn't a cloud in the sky, yet not a single star was shining. There they were, gathered at the foot of the Hill.
Narrator: *Your head tingles. Wyll wants to show you what happened.*
Player: Allow Wyll to share his memory with you.
Narrator: *In the looming shadow of the mount, five groups of five figures each encircle a lofty totem.* *Atop each totem, a dragon's head is carved, and a massive orb held in its mouth. The cultists chant, first softly, then crying to the starless sky.* *There is a crack of thunder, a gust of wind - and a dragon's white head appears in the storm.* *As the maelstrom howls, Mizora's lips press to your ear. 'She will destroy Baldur's Gate. Grant me your soul - and I will give you the power to save it', she whispers.*
Wyll: She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: Is that how you lost your eye - in the battle with the Cult of the Dragon?
Wyll: It is. The one scar I ever bore of it. You were right, of course - the new eye is a sending stone, courtesy of Mizora. She uses it to track my location and call from a distance. I could flee to the Spine of the World or the depths of the Lowerdark, and still never shake her. She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: A brave choice. And a frightening one.
Wyll: I don't know that it was brave. I just know that it was right. The moment I agreed, I burned with the fires of Avernus and oozed the rot of Dis. The cultists choked on our poisons and burned from our flames. When we were done, all that remained were five greyed orbs atop a pile of ash. My soul was bound and my lips were sealed. She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.
Player: A brave choice. And a frightening one.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.

Karlach, the creature from Hell, will still threaten them. As will a thousand other perils. They aren't ready to get on the road on their own.

Wyll: We all die. But life's still worth the living. Otherwise, what's the point of it? But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.

Wyll: Then we share a similar affliction. For I've grown fond of you too. Though I can't say I've earned the honour. I haven't even managed to kill one measly devil. I'm hardly a prime catch. The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh bollocks - I told those idiots not to let anyone through. YOU. Name, rank, and reason for interrupting an active crime scene. For your sake, the last one better be bloody good.
Player: Are you Devella? Valeria sent me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: To fetch her another bottle of mead, no doubt. Yes, I'm Devella, the unfortunate colleague. Unless you've got useful information, leave me to my work. Duke Stelmane's dead - and I've got to find who killed her.
Player: I know more about Bhaal than anyone you'll find. You don't want to send me away.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Abhorrent?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: Tell her of the target list. Say nothing of your intentions.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods - that's it! Proof that I was right. Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right! I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this. I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal. He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network. There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself. Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: Not only is the cult back, it's spreading fast. I ran into some Bhaalists in the park.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: No doubt you found a trail of bodies in their wake? The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faern couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I've got better things to do than investigate a cult.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I suppose it was quite an ask... but perhaps you wouldn't mind doing me a different, smaller favour? There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

'She will destroy Baldur's Gate. Grant me your soul - and I will give you the power to save it', she whispers.*
Wyll: She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.

Wyll: She read the terms while two devils stood witness. And I said yes. One soul for one city.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Ikaron again?
Alfira: Which...? He was on the quiet side, but had a heart of gold. Back in the grove, he'd kept an eye on the kids. Gods, that feels like a lifetime ago. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: Rolan? The apprentice wizard?
Alfira: Yes. He shielded me and the kids while his brother and sister rushed the cultists. Cal and Lia were dragged away, along with the others. Rolan isn't... taking it so well. None of us, to be honest. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Wyll: Is that... the kid Kagha went after? Seems she's learned a new trick.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Arabella? You should be with your parents.
Arabella: That's who I'm looking for. Mum and pops, I mean. When Zevlor - when he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm. Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: Your parents are test-fodder stuffed full of needles, little orphan.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: People die, and that's that. You can stay in my camp, if you quit your blubbering.
Arabella: Yeah. All right. If that's what I gotta do.
InternalNodeContext: There is an identical node for other persuasion - this is a matter of me being lazy and using same stub text for both persuasion success, don't read too deep into that - EkatA
NodeContext: Take a big breath before line, trying to keep from crying.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well. And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution. How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Nym Orlith: You survived my brother? Let me know if you want to have a more calming time with me.
Player: Mamzell Amira said you could offer your services as a gift of her thanks.
Sorn Orlith: Or perhaps you have greater ambitions yet. Trust me, you don't want to miss my signature Menzoberranzan Love Trick.
Narrator: *Menzoberranzan love magic - a formidable practice, usually only reserved for pleasing the most insatiable matriarchs in the city of spiders.*
Nym Orlith: And is that your partner with you? What a gorgeous couple... perhaps we could come to an agreement.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.

Player: I want both of you. At the same time.
Sorn Orlith: We will only allow that if we know there is an evening of exceptional pleasure awaiting us. Usually one darling alone is not enough to match the two of us.
Player: Well, Sorn, you sound like a charming man. Let's go up together.
Lae'zel: Bah. You would break our bond for the sake of laying this - this is'lak?
Nym Orlith: If your beloved one wants to join, we could work out something to our mutual satisfaction.
Sorn Orlith: Two of us, two of you. Four gorgeous people.
Player: What an idea!
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Wyll: No, no. I want romance, not - not debauchery.
Player: It was a bad idea. I'm sorry.

Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web. Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus. She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.

Oyster Boy Dringo: Uhh, hi.
Player: Do you work here?
Oyster Boy Dringo: Yeah. I'm caring for the courier dogs. Mar'hyah's my boss. She's mean. But dad says she'll toughen me up.
Player: She seems like a bully.
Oyster Boy Dringo: She's an educator. She says if somebody doesn't listen, shout louder. And if they still don't listen, fetch the rod.
Angry Mar'hyah: Dringo! Get back to work! And you - what do you want? This is a private yard. You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods. Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you? Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her. I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things. I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you? We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: 'When the night is dark, stars shine brightest.' So keep on shining. It's going to be all right.

Withers: Ah, another. Thy name has been recorded. I shall be here in thy camp, for whenever thou hast need of my services.
Player: Not to be rude, but what are you?
Withers: There are many answers to that question. None are important.
Player: Skeletons aren't supposed to be able to talk.
Withers: Correct.
Player: Are you going to explain further?
Withers: No. No.
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing? Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: I could use those resurrection services right now.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: Please bring back Shadowheart. I can't live with what I did.
Withers: Thou didst not kill thine own friend. Thou offered thy friend as sacrifice. Their soul is in a place even I cannot peer into. A place no soul should venture. Death alone was not suffering enough for thine Urge. Thou shouldst fear thyself. Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I would like to collect one of my fallen companions.
Withers: Which of them dost thou require?
Player: I'd like you to return Jaheira. Here's the gold.

Nere: Finally. Worthless slaves. Your incompetence has been my ruin.
NodeContext: Intense but quietly so. ZHIL loo-NIN! Rising, seething anger. Only the last word should be louder.
Player: Touch another innocent and I'll take your head, Nere. Stop! No more innocents will die today, Nere.
Nere: You care for the weak, True Soul. Most curious.
NodeContext: Quiet.
Player: Of course I care. I can't let these gnomes suffer.
Nere: The Absolute demands their slaughter. Yet here you stand, in bold defiance. A test - yes, you must be. The Absolute bade you to try Nere's faith. Thrinn. Carve out their heart and serve it to the roth. If they are indeed a True Soul, let the Absolute save them.
Player: Your god. My oath. Let us see which prevails.
Nere: You are a traitor.
Narrator: *The elder's disgust grips your head like a vice - yet he remains silent.*
Nere: Ah - another treacherous soul walks among us. Isn't that right, Brithvar?
Elder Brithvar: You been a shit since I laid eyes on you, red-eye. Go on, try and gut me. I ain't going down easy.
Nere: Direct your blade at the heretic, duergar. You shall have your coin.
Elder Brithvar: You're damned right I'll have it. Me and that one, we got a deal. We beat your arse and dig the dues out from your carcass.
Nere: You bargained with this wretch? How vexing. Nere is not without mercy, True Soul. The rat has given you a chance to earn my favour. Strike him down. Prove your faith.
Player: Side with Brithvar and the rebels.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn? Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Sorn Orlith: I know that look in your eye. Since being with me, you feel as if you are a Northdark Cavern: a hole that can only be filled by Drow.
Nym Orlith: Without the fungal infestations, I hope.
Player: Mamzell Amira said you could offer your services as a gift of her thanks.
Sorn Orlith: Or perhaps you have greater ambitions yet. Trust me, you don't want to miss my signature Menzoberranzan Love Trick.
Narrator: *Menzoberranzan love magic - a formidable practice, usually only reserved for pleasing the most insatiable matriarchs in the city of spiders.*
Nym Orlith: And is that your partner with you? What a gorgeous couple... perhaps we could come to an agreement.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?

Player: You two look uncannily alike.
Sorn Orlith: We are twins.
Player: You don't actually lie with one another... do you?
Sorn Orlith: We can make up a little show of kissing each other, but when we are hired at the same time, there are often many other clients in the room to attend to.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: I would like to hire both of you. And I hope my partner will join us as well.
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Wyll: No, no. I want romance, not - not debauchery.
Player: It was a bad idea. I'm sorry.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Some of us fought back - or tried to. But it was hopeless. All I could do was run.
Player: Running was the right call.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

Oyster Boy Dringo: Uhh, hi.
Player: Do you work here?
Oyster Boy Dringo: Yeah. I'm caring for the courier dogs. Mar'hyah's my boss. She's mean. But dad says she'll toughen me up. That's why I need to work hard in the kennels every day. To get tough.
Angry Mar'hyah: Dringo! Get back to work! And you - what do you want? This is a private yard. You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Whistle for Scratch.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dog approaches player
Oyster Boy Dringo: Scratch! It's good to see you boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut up, Dringo. And get back to work! And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy. This dog is property of Sword Coast Couriers. I'll take him off your hands now.
Player: He is not 'property,' he is Scratch. Don't you dare threaten him.
Angry Mar'hyah: I can do whatever I please - he's my dog. Now get out - this is a private yard.
Player: I'll break every bone in your body before I let you hurt that dog.
Angry Mar'hyah: You - you'll do no such thing.
Oyster Boy Dringo: It's not just Scratch. She's always hurting the dogs.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut your mouth, Dringo. Last warning.
Player: You have lost your way, hound-keeper. Leave, before I teach you to respect these creatures properly.

Angry Mar'hyah: Fine. You think you can do a better job without me - be my guest. They're a useless bunch of mongrels. You're welcome to them!

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *The queen who brings conquest to the heavens, sundering planets, destroying the very stars.* *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Kneel: choke down your brutal pride.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Gale: How generous of you - but perhaps you've forgotten we need it ourselves? That thing is keeping us safe.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO. I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: No. In fact, maybe I'll free the one inside.

Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side. There is a ruin, some way outside of Last Light. I caught a glimpse of fresh blooms there, but did not investigate further. I shall mark it upon your map.

Nere: Ah - I see treachery at every turn. Not every duergar proves faithful to the Absolute. Nere is not without mercy, True Soul. These overgrown rats have given you a chance to earn my favour. Strike them down. Prove your faith.

Raphael: Your move, Mol.
NodeContext: Says the cat to the mouse
Mol: You trapped me. I didn't even want to take this one.
Raphael: Calimshan rules, dear. The first piece touched is the first piece moved.
Mol: That's garbage. No matter where the knight goes, I'm gonna lose it.
Raphael: Then make the sacrifice useful. Guard your Mystra, or come for my Cyric.
Karlach: What's going on here?
Mol: Oh, hey. I remember you. Booked it from the grove before the druids could kick us. Smart. You smart enough for lanceboard? It's my first time playing.
Narrator: *The keen gleam in Mol's eyes reveals the lie. She knows the game well, and she wants to win.*
Gale: He's laid a fine trap for you, Mol. But it looks to me like his Cyric could be dethroned.
Player: You shouldn't be playing games with this man. He's a devil.
Mol: Sure, and I'm Zariel's firstborn. Don't be distractin' me.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mol hastily moves the piece in her hand to another square.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mol and Raphael exchange pieces, ending the game as he captures her king.
Mol: Hells. Thought I had you.
Raphael: They always do. You came close, though. All you needed was a dash more courage. You will remember that, won't you, when you consider my offer?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mol nods, then folds the pieces into the landboard to put them away, disappearing out of view. When Raphael is centered on screen again, he is standing and smiling at the player.
Raphael: What a lovely specimen she is. A blushing apple, begging to be plucked.
Karlach: Please let me smack this creep.
Raphael: Her victory was hollow, of course. Frankly, I expected better of you - did Mol ask to have your god win the game for her?
Player: A god is quite handy when dealing with devils.
Raphael: Oh, I promise on every treasure I own... you've never dealt with a devil like me before.
NodeContext: with a wicked, knowing grin
Raphael: But don't you worry about Mol - it goes without saying she still has the unconditional freedom to choose the only option she has left. Besides, I do enjoy being in this neighbourhood again. It has such a rich history of abject tragedy. And tragedy, my friend, well there's my bread and bloody butter.
Player: Just stay away from Mol, you hear?

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Karlach: Hey! That's Arabella. Kid from the druid's grove. That snake woman nearly did her in. Looks like she's learned a thing or two.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Arabella? You should be with your parents.
Arabella: That's who I'm looking for. Mum and pops, I mean. When Zevlor - when he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: I'll think about it. My hands are full with these cultists.
Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: I've rarely seen corpses as violated as theirs are - it was quite the sight.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: Live, grow up, and make your path anew by my side.
Arabella: You're right. If I become strong, they will look on me with pride from beyond. All right. I'll go to the camp, like you said. Just... ...just don't leave me.

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed. Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I'm not a refugee.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Well, do you have the means to support yourself? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. I will not pay to enter my own city.
Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.
Player: I can take care of myself. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Gauntlet Edwynna: Right. Article 30.1.5 of the Council's Decree on Extraordinary Wartime Measures. I am confiscating that. The city thanks you for your contribution. Your name?
Player: My name is [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: Remain silent.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.
Player: I'm here to enlist - figured the Fist could use a hand.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The steel watcher steps forward and begins to scan the player's eyes.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.
Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You may not carry a mind flayer parasite, but it sees you - knows you.* *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.* *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.* *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.* *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.* *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.* *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mindmeld with steel watcher ends
Player: Consent to arrest.

Ptaris: Who are you? Another who needs to learn the difference between right and wrong?

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crche?*
Player: It's nice to see you again, githyanki.
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that! I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Don't worry - I'm not here to judge.
Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I fight, eat, drink, love, and hate with everything I have - that is all that matters.
Ptaris: Such an empty and  meaningless life. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: I live by my own code, though not the one you speak of.
Ptaris: Then your code is flawed. Your actions cannot be defended. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: Ungrateful yank. Our kin would have destroyed you if it wasn't for me. You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand. Father saved me. I was a nasty, evil thing, but his treatments made me good. I - I'm cured.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you. I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares. NodeContext: Bemused, snarky

And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.
