[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you? We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Just take it one step at a time.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.
 Anyhow. Piss off.
Player: I met the people looking for you. They say you're a killer - a fiend.
Karlach: And you believe them? Those bastards are trying to feed you a crock of shit. Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: Hold on - the people I spoke to were paladins, not devils.
Karlach: Sure they were - and I'm Tiamat's left tit. I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood. Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: That doesn't sound ideal.
Karlach: It's not - it's a shitting catastrophe. But at least I'm out.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.* *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.* *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms? I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: Not many did.
Karlach: Poor bastards. I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: You were expecting the ship?
Karlach: No - I just saw a chance and I took it. That ship could have been heading for Sigil or Limbo for all I cared - anything was better than staying. And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse. Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me. I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset. Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Why don't you just run?
Karlach: They're not the kind of people you can run from. I need them dead.
Player: I'll take them down.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeons voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the humans belly, but its a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: Depends on how you define 'good'.
Ptaris: There is only one way. The Ptarian code. Do you follow it? The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The code of Bahamut. His guidance leads me in all things.
Ptaris: Do you really believe that? You are unfit to say his name. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I never should have saved you. But I'm happy to rectify my mistake. You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you. You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you. It must not have been easy to escape. I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares. You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable. To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us. The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: This weapon - what does it do?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: What business is that of yours? Suffice to say, my queen wants it. But know that you will have been instrumental in stopping the Grand Design. Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va. The weapon. Now.
Player: I have the weapon - I would say that puts me in a strong position to bargain with you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Is that so? Well, then - humour me. What would you ask of an Inquisitor?
NodeContext: Bemused, snarky
Player: Give me a treasure from the Githyanki Empire's coffers. One of immense power.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You would lay claim to our hard-won treasures? You seek power but do not seek to strive for it? A fool's request. Denied. Give me the weapon. Now. So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: It's been a while, my friend. I saw the explosion from across the pond - should've known you'd be right in the thick of it. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you. But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more. Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What do you think, Wulbren?
Wulbren Bongle: I think that if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check. Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check. You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes. I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around. Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention. I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: There's no honour among thieves, Barcus - and same goes for the Ironhands. Take Wulbren's place, lead them yourself! Perhaps the Ironhand Gnomes need a new leader. What say you, Barcus?

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Are you all right?
Wyll: Oh, I'm deeply proud of you. A touch less so of myself. In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night. These people are still in danger. A thousand perils still threaten them. They aren't ready to get on the road on their own.
Player: We have won this day! Danger is for tomorrow.
Wyll: Your words cheer me more than any party could. But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: Clearly Mol has put you up to stealing my britches so you can turn them into a flag for her gang. Not that I'd necessarily object. Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: Nope. Guess again.
Wyll: Let me think... Why are you really here? You're running away from Gale's cooking. It's delicious, don't get me wrong, but that man wouldn't eat a vegetable unless Mystra herself commanded it. Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Keep trying!
Wyll: It's a long shot, but - maybe you've grown fond of me. Gods know I've grown fond of you.
Player: Maybe just a little.
Wyll: Then we share a similar affliction. For I've grown fond of you too. Though I can't say I've earned the honour. The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.
Player: Maybe a kiss would prove my affections.
Wyll: *Sigh.* You drive a hard bargain. But just the one.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Wyll stoops to share a quick kiss.
Wyll: I - well, then. Erm, you've got a party to get back to. After all, tonight is about you. There will be another time for us.

Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
Narrator: *Within Ravengard's memories, you find Counsellor Florrick. She is confined in a cell, right here in Wyrm's Rock.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready? Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web. Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus. She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Lae'zel: Punished? Then Florrick's been captured. Or worse.
Player: Leave the duke's mind unexplored.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready? Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: The Absolute's time has come. She will bring glory to the city.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Not just glory. Paradise. Faern suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.
Narrator: *Tyr's fury glows within you. Despite Ravengard's words, the Lord of Justice has remained loyal to you, as you have to him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But Baldur's Gate will soon burn bright. A beacon to light the heavens. Gortash and I will ignite the final spark. And that, True Soul, is the greatest of goods. Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: By the gods, what have they made of the city's great hero?

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel not yet kneeling at corpse. What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. When he died, a tadpole came out of his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: He crowed about what fools you all were to trust him.
Isobel: If that's true, then he was right. You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: Such as?
Isobel: Your trip to the Towers, for one. And what you plan to do there. A True Soul with a mind of their own... Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell. Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|
Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect. It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers. But there are places it won't help - places where the curse is darker. Stronger. The cultists are able to traverse even the deepest shadows, though. I don't know how - the Harpers are trying to figure it out.
Shadowheart: Selnite magic. Dark Lady forgive me.
NodeContext: Low-key revulsion
Isobel: Good nose. Like a nasty little terrier.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: The Absolute's voice is gone, but I still hear its echoes - reflections of reflections. As you wish.
Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm. You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need. First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together. I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? My soul lies with the city. But...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But what, Wyll?
Wyll: I have slain monsters, faced illithids, guarded the helpless. To be a duke - is this the destiny I've awaited? Is the nobility my calling?
Player: Wyll, Mizora could be a dangerous influence. You can't accept your father's offer.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There will be no Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard.
Wyll: I am the defender of the weak, I am the stalker of devils - I am the Blade of Frontiers!
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My boy, my blood. Let it be known: the Blade is on the hunt. Feel his sting! Hail the Blade of Frontiers!
Minsc: The Blade of Frontiers!
Narrator: *A calm settles over you. The elder brain is a menace - but with the Blade of Frontiers at your side, you know you can triumph.*

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?

Counsellor Florrick: Yes, Wyll. The drow have your father.
Player: Ravengard? I know that name.

But please, find him and return him to the city.
Wyll: Trust us to see it through, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: On my oath: I will see Duke Ravengard rescued, and his captors vanquished. I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him. A True Soul with a soul. Imagine. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll enters camp. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of Wyll, and Mizora in devil form rises from it.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Karlach: Holy fucking hells.
Wyll: Enough games - they took my father. Now what?
Mizora: Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.
Wyll: Shit. What did you do, Mizora?
Mizora: I had no hand in your father's death, Wyll. But that doesn't mean he might not still live.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Wyll: What are you proposing?
Mizora: A life for a life. No contract is ended without sacrifice. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Leave him dead. When the city's free, you can take his place.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Stay quiet, and watch Wyll dance.
Wyll: Oh! Sorry. I didn't see you standing there. Lost in the steps, truth be told. I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: Keep practising. I'm sure you'll get better... eventually...
Wyll: Maybe. But I'm not so keen to perform solo. A duet's always been more my style. Which is to say - May I have this dance?
Player: Cocky, don't you think? Threaten my life, then try to cosy up after?
Wyll: I deserve that. And I wish I could give more than 'sorry's in return. But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Gather your strength and leap into the air.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player leaps into the air, but then stumbles, rights themselves, and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: Ha ha - ahem. Don't you worry. It takes years to master the Vollante.
Player: You're a beautiful dancer. I'm sure you'll teach me in no time.
Wyll: I'll show you everything I know, and then some - I promise. But perhaps we might try a more intimate style.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Press your lips against Wyll's.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll, then pulls away.
Wyll: So much shadow around us. To think I almost missed the light. Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: Move in for another kiss.
Wyll: *Sigh.* I've drunk wines from Daggerford to Cormyr, but I've never known a taste as rich as yours. Gods damn it. You almost make me forget myself. But I still keep faith in the old tales of love, the once-upon-a-times and the happily-ever-afters. I'd like to do this the proper way. The way of the old romances sung by the bards. Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern. I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Thank you so - no, it can't be. Wyll, by the living gods, what's happened to you?
Player: A story best left for calmer days, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: Calmer days are not soon to come, Wyll - as I'm sure you know.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Pavel. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Ito - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Pavel: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: On my oath: I will see Duke Ravengard rescued, and his captors vanquished. I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general

NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.

Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters the camp, Wyll waiting at a side, fully in view. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of you and Wyll, shocked/surprise, and Mizora in devil form rises from it, maybe can have a turn and a noble pose at the end.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Mizora: Come, Sisters, be my testament. Notum sit in Baator.
Arbiter Cirrus: Notum sit in Baator.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Interesting. I don't recall sending out invitations to the Sisters of Justice.
Mizora: You do not call upon the Sisters. They come when the Hells demand witness. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Enough, Mizora. My father is dead. Say your piece.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll has suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

Barcus Wroot: Well. You... did it! I shouldn't be surprised, considering our history. And yet...
Player: Don't sound so surprised.
Barcus Wroot: Nothing good happens in the Underdark. I know someone of your background would fit right in in that heart of horrors, but for others of us it's quite a frightening prospect. And so... to Moonrise Towers I go.
Karlach: Barcus has the right idea. We've got to get to Moonrise too - and soon.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what Wulbren and the others were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what Wulbren and the others were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Farewell, Barcus - I wish you luck with your search.

Narrator: *Your tadpole resonates with Ravengard's. The exhausted Grand Duke is a flurry of emotion - gratitude and relief, anger and deep pain.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: W-Wyll? It - it can't be. By Balduran's graces, have you fallen so far that Avernus has taken you? First you cleave my heart in twain. Now you shatter it into pieces. My son a monster, twisted almost beyond recognition. To think my blood flows through those veins. Is this my fate - to rise from death into a hell of my own boy's making?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now. It is exactly what I think.
Player: I'm beginning to think we should have let you drown.
Wyll: No, please. Father - let me show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: Say nothing.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: Waking a dragon doesn't sound like a good idea.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is no ordinary dragon. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. There is a tome - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. I once held a copy, but it was stolen. Find it, let it set the path before you. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Zevlor: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.
Karlach: Excuse you.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Karlach: What? Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: My sources say otherwise. Not a devil? Prove it.
Karlach: How should I do that exactly? Carve out my soul to serve with a nice side of turnips? If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Gale: Easy, Wyll. She's no devil. There's no fight to be had here.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: No. No second-guessing. The devil dies - now.

Barcus Wroot: Well. You... did it! I shouldn't be surprised, considering our history. And yet...
Player: Don't sound so surprised.
Barcus Wroot: Nothing good happens in the Underdark. I know someone of your background would fit right in in that heart of horrors, but for others of us it's quite a frightening prospect. And so... to Moonrise Towers I go.
Shadowheart: Moonrise? There's a lot resting on what we find in that place. It had better deliver.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Farewell, Barcus - I wish you luck with your search.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him. A True Soul with a soul. Imagine. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Karlach: NodeContext: teasing astarion, but with an edge Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Astarion: Now, now, children - let's not lose our heads. Figuratively or literally.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: How can I make peace with the monster I was sent to kill?
Karlach: You know monsters, right? Better than anyone. Look into my eyes. Can't you see I'm not what you think?
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Narrator: *Your tadpole resonates with Ravengard's. The exhausted Grand Duke is a flurry of emotion - gratitude and relief, anger and deep pain.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: W-Wyll? It - it can't be. By Balduran's graces, have you fallen so far that Avernus has taken you? First you cleave my heart in twain. Now you shatter it into pieces. My son a monster, twisted almost beyond recognition. To think my blood flows through those veins. Is this my fate - to be freed from Gortash's hell only to be trapped in yours?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now. It is exactly what I think.
Player: I'm beginning to think we should have let you drown.
Wyll: No, please. Father - let me show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's the truth, Ravengard. Wyll has always been a faithful defender of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: What lessons do you mean?
Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. I remember them well. You made me recite them every morning.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: So you do. And I thought you'd abandoned them, more fool me. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Novice Grumm: Shit - True Soul Nere's nothing but grub-chow now. Listen up, bastards - I'm taking charge. Clean your 'nads and pack up.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: We're marching to Moonrise. And no death-curse'll be stopping us.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Wyll: Speak up. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*

Novice Grumm: Shit - suppose you're right. No use hauling dead weight. Gnomes - it's your lucky day. Get your squat arses moving, before I take a brand to them.

True Soul Gut: Another special visitor. You've been touched by the Absolute, haven't you? Priestess Gut needs to touch you, too. Hold out your arm so I can mark you.
Lae'zel: Enough stalling. Finish her, and be quick about it.
Player: I'm here to kill you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Stay quiet, and watch Wyll dance.
Wyll: Oh! Sorry. I didn't see you standing there. Lost in the steps, truth be told. I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: Trust me. I don't think you could fail anyone if you tried.
Wyll: I know a few people who might beg to differ. But the only one that matters is here with me now. May I have this dance?
Player: I'd like to, but I'm afraid I'll trip over my own feet.
Wyll: Don't worry. It's not really about the dance. It's about who's we're dancing with. But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Perform a simple cadence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player performs a simple dance move and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: Bravo. Bravo!
Player: Smile nervously.
Wyll: No need to be modest, you were a delight to behold. Now perhaps we might try a more - intimate style.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Invite him closer with a knowing look - it's what you both want.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll pushes his lips against the player's, then pulls away.
Wyll: So much shadow around us. To think I almost missed the light. Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: Good night, Wyll.
Wyll: Good night. And thank you. For the dance, I mean. I won't forget it.

Karlach: What is it? Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Lae'zel: Control yourself, Wyll. I understand bloodthirst. But this is no time to quench it.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: You, yourself?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: I'm not sure I can see into forever. But it's still a nice view.
Wyll: My favourite in all of the Coast. All of Faern, even. Not even the Sea of Stars could rival its magnificence - Nor could it rival yours.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: I'm not sure. It's a lot to take in.
Wyll: It is. I swear, I've lived a thousand lives since I've known you. But I'm ready to live a thousand more, if you can bear me.
Player: Yes. I want to be with you, for as long as you'll have me.
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Shit, yes. Let's see the snake this devil's been hiding.

Player: Go on. A wyrm? Are you saying there's a dragon living under the city?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A bronze dragon, yes. He sleeps beneath us even now, awaiting a hero to rouse him. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. There is a tome - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. I once held a copy, but it was stolen. Find it, let it set the path before you. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm. You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need. First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together. I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? I look the part of a fiend.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will tell the citizens and the patriars of your good works. They will know you carry your father's banner. But it is true - you are still under the she-devil's thumb...
Narrator: *Uncertainty fills the air. Wyll has reached a fork in his path. In which direction will he travel?*
Player: I trust you, Wyll. Follow your heart, wherever it leads.
Wyll: I fought to right the wrongs of the Coast, to slay the men and monsters that hunt the helpless. It is in the wilds that I find my courage, not in the halls of Upper City estates. There will be no Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard. And there will be no Blade of Frontiers. I am now the Blade of Avernus. For as long as demons and devils imperil the Sword Coast, they will be my prey.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Then go with my blessing. Be Faern's great defender. Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. Let these be the lights that guide you, my son. Hail the Blade of Avernus!
Minsc: The Blade of Avernus!
Narrator: *A calm settles over you. The elder brain is a menace - but with the Blade of Avernus at your side, you know you can triumph.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Stay quiet, and watch Wyll dance.
Wyll: Oh! Sorry. I didn't see you standing there. Lost in the steps, truth be told. I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: Keep practising. I'm sure you'll get better... eventually...
Wyll: Maybe. But I'm not so keen to perform solo. A duet's always been more my style. Which is to say - May I have this dance?
Player: Cocky, don't you think? Threaten my life, then try to cosy up after?
Wyll: I deserve that. And I wish I could give more than 'sorry's in return. But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: First you cleave my heart in twain. Now you shatter it into pieces. My son a monster, twisted almost beyond recognition. To think my blood flows through those veins. Is this my fate - to be freed from Gortash's hell only to be trapped in yours?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now. It is exactly what I think.
Player: Your son sacrificed his soul to save yours. He had no choice.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is always a choice.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: Heh. I bet you feel like a real bastard right about now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I do. And I should. My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: A wyrm? Are you saying there's a dragon living under the city?

Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Nice form. Where'd you learn to dance like that?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll does a few more turns and steps, than faces the player and smiles.
Wyll: I've attended my share of fancy balls and masquerades. A few elegant moves can turn all the right heads. Figured it was time to brush up on my skills. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner. I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: A new partner? And who might that be?
Wyll: As luck would have it, they just arrived. May I have this dance?
Player: I'd like to, but I'm afraid I'll trip over my own feet.
Wyll: Don't worry. It's not really about the dance. It's about who's we're dancing with. But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Give a twirl. A calm twirl.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player does a fun but expertless twirl and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: How utterly charming!
Player: Beats all that fancy flitting around you were doing.
Wyll: Does it now? Then let's see how you fare with a less - energetic style.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Turn your head away.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll and the player step away from each other. After an awkward moment, he smiles.
Wyll: Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: Good night, Wyll.
Wyll: Good night. And thank you. For the dance, I mean. I won't forget it.

Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: How can I make peace with the monster I was sent to kill?
Karlach: You know monsters, right? Better than anyone. Look into my eyes. Can't you see I'm not what you think?
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Shorter Appearance Sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Interesting. I don't recall sending out invitations to the Sisters of Justice.
Mizora: You do not call upon the Sisters. They come when the Hells demand witness. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Father is dead? Godsdamned devil. Why are you here?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll has suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Is this my fate - to be freed from Gortash's hell only to be trapped in yours?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now. It is exactly what I think.
Player: Your son sacrificed his soul to save yours. He had no choice.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is always a choice.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: Heh. I bet you feel like a real bastard right about now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I do. And I should. My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: What lessons do you mean?
Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. I remember them well. You made me recite them every morning.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: So you do. And I thought you'd abandoned them, more fool me. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Your faith in Wyll is well-founded. We will seek the wyrm and ask for his help.

Zevlor: Now that's settled. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.

Mizora: Do you suppose? I'd call the timing most perfect, myself. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.

Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
