[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll doesn't need to wait six months.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Bring back your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A devil's plaything awaiting a future in the Hells. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The archdevil Zariel?
Wyll: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: Smile and take Wyll's hand.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: I'm not sure I can see into forever. But it's still a nice view.
Wyll: My favourite in all of the Coast. All of Faern, even. Not even the Sea of Stars could rival its magnificence - Nor could it rival yours.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: I'm not sure. It's a lot to take in.
Wyll: It is. I swear, I've lived a thousand lives since I've known you. But I'm ready to live a thousand more, if you can bear me.
Player: Yes. I want to be with you, for as long as you'll have me.
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after! Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: It's about time. Let's see what the Blade can do with his weapon. Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll enters camp. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of Wyll, and Mizora in devil form rises from it.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Karlach: Holy fucking hells.
Wyll: Interesting. I don't recall sending out invitations to the Sisters of Justice.
Mizora: You do not call upon the Sisters. They come when the Hells demand witness. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness. Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.
Wyll: Shit. What did you do, Mizora?
Mizora: I had no hand in your father's death, Wyll. But that doesn't mean he might not still live.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Wyll: Then break it already. I suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.

GROUP_Emperors: Ansur. It's been too long.
Wyll: Balduran? No. I don't believe it.
Player: He called you Balduran?
GROUP_Emperors: A name I once answered to. A name I did not expect to hear again, least of all from the mouth of an old friend.
Ansur: Friend, yes - and more. Until you killed me. Have you come to dance on my bones, Balduran? Was slaying me not satisfaction enough?
GROUP_Emperors: Satisfaction? No. You left me no choice.
Ansur: You had every choice. You were becoming illithid. I offered you merciful death; you chose to fight. And now you bring your thrall before me. How far has the great Balduran fallen?
Player: Thrall?! I am no thrall.
Narrator: *Stillness. Ansur's consciousness hovers just above yours, searching, seeing.*
GROUP_Emperors: Dear Ansur -
Ansur: Enough! I gave you everything, Balduran - and you repaid me in slaughter. It is time I return the favour. I am the Heart of the Gate. I am The One Who Roars. Let my bones rise and the storms gather. Witness, Balduran - the final tempest has come. This time, you will not escape it!

Narrator: *Your tadpole resonates with Ravengard's. The exhausted Grand Duke is a flurry of emotion - gratitude and relief, anger and deep pain.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: W-Wyll? It - it can't be. By Balduran's graces, have you fallen so far that Avernus has taken you? First you cleave my heart in twain. Now you shatter it into pieces. My son a monster, twisted almost beyond recognition. To think my blood flows through those veins. Is this my fate - to rise from death into a hell of my own boy's making?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now. It is exactly what I think.
Player: Your son sacrificed his soul to save yours. He had no choice.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is always a choice.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's the truth, Ravengard. Wyll has always been a faithful defender of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: What lessons do you mean?
Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. I remember them well. You made me recite them every morning.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: So you do. And I thought you'd abandoned them, more fool me. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. There is a tome - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. I once held a copy, but it was stolen. Find it, let it set the path before you. Let it set the path before you.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: I'm not sure I can see into forever. But it's still a nice view.
Wyll: My favourite in all of the Coast. All of Faern, even. Not even the Sea of Stars could rival its magnificence - Nor could it rival yours.

Player: Gods, this is just like you to judge without knowing the whole story.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I know the story. You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now.

Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.

Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's the truth, Ravengard. Wyll has always been a faithful defender of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: A wyrm? Are you saying there's a dragon living under the city?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A bronze dragon, yes. He sleeps beneath us even now, awaiting a hero to rouse him. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Your faith in Wyll is well-founded. We will seek the wyrm and ask for his help.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Together, Wyll and I will make Baldur's Gate the brightest gem aside the Sword Sea. The Heart of the Gate will prevail. As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.

Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.

You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need. First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together. I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? I look the part of a fiend. A half-devil possesses my very soul.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will tell the citizens and the patriars of your good works. They will know you carry your father's banner. But it is true - you are still under the she-devil's thumb...

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Karlach: Holy fucking hells.
Wyll: What are you up to, Mizora?
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness. Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.
Wyll: Let them have him, then. He was never any use to me.
Mizora: You say that. But minds can change in the span of a snap - and not every death is forever.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Wyll: Then break it now, Mizora. I don't need to wait six months.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Break the pact, Wyll. You deserve your freedom.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approached the dragon bones in the Wyrmway.

JLatino: CUT "As they get close, or click on the helm of balduran (TBD), the helm trmbles, and spiritual energy flows from it."

JLatino: CUT "As they get close, or click on the helm of balduran (TBD), the helm trmbles, and spiritual energy flows from it."
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The energy flows into the dragon bones on the ground. Ghostly lights spark inside the eye sockets of the skull.

JLatino: CUT "A skeletal dragon assembles and rises, looming over the players, terrifying in its presence."

JLatino: CUT "A skeletal dragon assembles and rises, looming over the players, terrifying in its presence."
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The present players are raised into the air and turned on their back in the style of a speak with dead. They hover above the ground.
Narrator: *The dragon's spirit floods your mind and memory in a great torrent of power. He is with you, he is within you, he is you.* *The next words that spill from your mouth are not yours, but the wyrm's.*
Ansur: I am Ansur, Heart of the Gate - butchered in flesh, risen in spirit.
Player: Try to scream.
Narrator: *Your throat thickens with stifled air. Ansur's thoughts flow out of you as if they were your own.* *The spirit pauses, and you feel the Astral Prism stir. Ansur senses the Emperor's presence within it.*
Ansur: Answer me, faessi: why have you come?
NodeContext: face-SEE (coward)
Player: My father sent me - Duke Ulder Ravengard. We need your help.
Narrator: *A deep sigh resonates within you. The torrent stills, only disturbed by the dragon's next words.*
Ansur: Vrak. My words aren't meant for you - they're meant for him.
NodeContext: vrahk. 'Child'. ux bah-hah-MYOO-tee 'Dragonborn'
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The space changes - a vision space. The Emperor appears in flesh. When the player speaks

JLatino: CUT ", we see Ansur's animated bones behind."

JLatino: CUT ", we see Ansur's animated bones behind."
Narrator: *The Emperor stirs in the Astral Prism, then in you - calm, curious, and detached.*
Ansur: Balduran. Your presence has stirred me, as it ever did. I am awakened.
GROUP_Emperors: Ansur. It's been too long.
Wyll: Balduran? No. I don't believe it.
Player: Will someone please explain to me what's going on?
GROUP_Emperors: We knew each other once - long ago. We crossed the Calim together and sailed Yal Tengri. We built a city by the sea. Ansur was my friend.
Ansur: Friend, yes - and more. Until you killed me. Have you come to dance on my bones, Balduran? Was slaying me not satisfaction enough?
GROUP_Emperors: Satisfaction? No. You left me no choice.
Ansur: You had every choice. You were becoming illithid. I offered you merciful death; you chose to fight. And now you bring your thrall before me. How far has the great Balduran fallen?
Player: A touching reunion. Now how about letting me go?
Narrator: *Stillness. Ansur's consciousness hovers just above yours, searching, seeing.*
GROUP_Emperors: Dear Ansur -
Ansur: Enough! I gave you everything, Balduran - and you repaid me in slaughter. It is time I return the favour. I am the Heart of the Gate. I am The One Who Roars. Let my bones rise and the storms gather. Witness, Balduran - the final tempest has come. This time, you will not escape it!

Karlach: I'm exhausted. Weird. Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: My sources say otherwise. Not a devil? Prove it.
Karlach: How should I do that exactly? Carve out my soul to serve with a nice side of turnips? If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Lae'zel: Control yourself, Wyll. I understand bloodthirst. But this is no time to quench it.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Thank you so - no, it can't be. Wyll, by the living gods, what's happened to you?
Player: A story best left for calmer days, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: Calmer days are not soon to come, Wyll - as I'm sure you know.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Ito. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Pavel - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Pavel: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: Goblins take their prisoners to Moonrise Towers. That's where we'll find the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: On my oath: I will see Duke Ravengard rescued, and his captors vanquished. I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

Narrator: *Your tadpole resonates with your father's. The exhausted Grand Duke is a flurry of emotion - gratitude and relief, anger and deep pain.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My own son, still the she-devil's toy. Is this my fate - to rise from death into a hell of my own boy's making?
Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now. It is exactly what I think.
Player: Wyll's devoted his life to protecting the Coast. He's used his power wisely.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is no wise use of the Hells' powers.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's time you two made up. We've got a city to save.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: All too right. My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: Waking a dragon doesn't sound like a good idea.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is no ordinary dragon. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Thank you so - no, it can't be. Wyll, by the living gods, what's happened to you?
Player: Let's just say I got mixed up with the wrong crowd.
Counsellor Florrick: Yes. As Ravengard told me, where his son treads, the Hells fires are sure to burn.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Pavel. Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Pavel - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke. Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Ito: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city. And you - I must ask again for your aid. Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort. May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: I'll rescue Duke Ravengard. You have my word. I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Stay quiet, and watch Wyll dance.
Wyll: Oh! Sorry. I didn't see you standing there. Lost in the steps, truth be told. I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: Trust me. I don't think you could fail anyone if you tried.
Wyll: I know a few people who might beg to differ. But the only one that matters is here with me now. May I have this dance?
Player: Wyll, I'd love nothing more than to dance with you. But I fear I'd burn you to a crisp.
Wyll: About that. You only burn hottest when your emotions are aflare, right? Anger, excitement, fear... but a dance can be meditative. Calming. If you think you can put your hand in mine without singeing it off, I'm willing to try.
Player: I could really hurt you.
Wyll: But you won't.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Perform a simple cadence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player attempts a dance move but trips a bit, then smiles at Wyll
Wyll: Ha ha - ahem. Don't you worry. It takes years to master the Vollante.
Player: Well, not all of us were born with silver spoons in our mouths.
Wyll: Fair enough. Perhaps a less energetic style would suit you better.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Invite him closer with a knowing look - it's what you both want.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll pushes his lips against the player's, then pulls away.
Wyll: So much shadow around us. To think I almost missed the light. Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: Good night, Wyll.
Wyll: Good night. And thank you. For the dance, I mean. I won't forget it.

Barcus Wroot: Well. You... did it! I shouldn't be surprised, considering our history. And yet...
Player: You're free - go on.
Barcus Wroot: Free. Yes. Nothing good happens in the Underdark. I know someone of your background would fit right in in that heart of horrors, but for others of us it's quite a frightening prospect. And so... to Moonrise Towers I go.
Player: Do you know what Wulbren and the others were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what Wulbren and the others were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Farewell, Barcus - I wish you luck with your search.

Karlach: Oh, hi! Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: Dammit. This is an unwelcome complication.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The archdevil Zariel?
Wyll: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: All right. But this better be worth it.
Wyll: It is. I promise.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before - And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Take the acorn and nod.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: It's about time. Let's see what the Blade can do with his weapon. Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters the camp, Wyll waiting at a side, fully in view. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of you and Wyll, shocked/surprise, and Mizora in devil form rises from it, maybe can have a turn and a noble pose at the end.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Mizora: Come, Sisters, be my testament. Notum sit in Baator.
Arbiter Cirrus: Notum sit in Baator.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Please, introduce me to your friends.
Mizora: Feena, Cirrus. Arbiters for the Hells, exemplars of justice. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Enough, Mizora. My father is dead. Say your piece.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll has suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Save your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else: Me. I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before - And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: It's like watching a beached flounder flop back to the sea. Is that the idea?
Wyll: Oh goodness. Is it all that bad? I'm dreadfully out of practise. No better time to brush up on my skills, then. It would do me no good to fail my new partner. I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: A new partner? And who might that be?
Wyll: As luck would have it, they just arrived. May I have this dance?
Player: Dance? But there's no music.
Wyll: Our hearts can keep time. But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Gather your strength and leap into the air.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player leaps into the air, but then stumbles, rights themselves, and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: Ha ha - ahem. Don't you worry. It takes years to master the Vollante.
Player: You're a beautiful dancer. I'm sure you'll teach me in no time.
Wyll: I'll show you everything I know, and then some - I promise. But perhaps we might try a more intimate style.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Turn your head away.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll and the player step away from each other. After an awkward moment, he smiles.
Wyll: Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: Move in for another kiss.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll - he kisses back, then pulls away.
Wyll: *Sigh.* I've drunk wines from Daggerford to Cormyr, but I've never known a taste as rich as yours. Gods damn it. You almost make me forget myself. But I still keep faith in the old tales of love, the once-upon-a-times and the happily-ever-afters. I'd like to do this the proper way. The way of the old romances sung by the bards. Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Hail, my boy. As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me. I couldn't bear it if she died by my command. May the Triad guide her steps. As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me. I couldn't bear it if she died by my command. May the Triad guide her steps. As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me. I couldn't bear it if she died by my command. May the Triad guide her steps. As you wish.
Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm. You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need. First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together. I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? I look the part of a fiend.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will tell the citizens and the patriars of your good works. They will know you carry your father's banner. But it is true - you are still under the she-devil's thumb...
Narrator: *Uncertainty fills the air. Wyll has reached a fork in his path. In which direction will he travel?*
Player: Become a Grand Duke. Imagine the power you'll wield.
Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. These were the lessons my father taught me. Baldur's Gate is my home, and I am its servant. I will be relentless in my pursuit of the greatest good.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I would sooner die by Mizora's hand than let her endanger the city. I'll figure out a way.
Wyll: The Blade of Frontiers is no more. I will be Wyll Ravengard, son of Ulder, proud Duke of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son! Together, there is no army we cannot conquer and no wrong we cannot right. Hail Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Minsc: Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Narrator: *Wyll's courage and enthusiasm warms the air. With him at your side, the road ahead doesn't look so insurmountable.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after! Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Shit, yes. Let's see the snake this devil's been hiding.

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Outsiders, perhaps. But not me.
Zevlor: Lucky you. There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*

Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Barcus Wroot: Well. You... did it! I shouldn't be surprised, considering our history. And yet...
Player: Don't sound so surprised.
Barcus Wroot: Nothing good happens in the Underdark. As you know some of the Ironhand Gnomes - my friend Wulbren among them - have been taken prisoner in Moonrise Towers. They're not even going after him. I wish I were surprised. And so... to Moonrise Towers I go.
Shadowheart: Moonrise? There's a lot resting on what we find in that place. It had better deliver.
Player: Do you know what Wulbren and the others were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what the Ironhand Gnomes were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Do you know what Wulbren and the others were doing down here?
Barcus Wroot: No.
Player: Farewell, Barcus - I wish you luck with your search.

Zevlor: Ngh. Mragreshem.
NodeContext: mrag-RESH-em. Means 'shithead' in infernal. Zevlor has just woken up after being punched in the face by Aradin. He's groggy and pissed off.
Zevlor: A cheap shot. I should've expected that.
NodeContext: Disgust in his voice. His idiot enemy clocked him.
Player: Are you all right?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. Particularly if it's rid the grove of Aradin. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?

Player: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll - he kisses back, then pulls away.
Wyll: *Sigh.* I've drunk wines from Daggerford to Cormyr, but I've never known a taste as rich as yours. Gods damn it. You almost make me forget myself. But I still keep faith in the old tales of love, the once-upon-a-times and the happily-ever-afters. I'd like to do this the proper way. The way of the old romances sung by the bards. Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

Zevlor: Now that's settled. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: What is this place?
Zevlor: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: 'The Descent'? What is that?
Zevlor: I'm surprised you haven't heard of it. The High Overseer - our grand protector - signed a pact with devils. It dragged Elturel straight to Hell. Lucky for us, a group of adventurers found a way to bring the city back. Afterwards, people looked at us and just saw 'devilkin'. No different from the druids here, really. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Zevlor: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: What is this place?
Zevlor: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.

Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Player: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: A scorched throat, a few hairs singed off. Nothing a bit of time and fresh air can't cure. Gauntlet, a new duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed. Report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Wyll: No, it can't be. You mean, they've taken -
Counsellor Florrick: Yes, Wyll. The drow have your father.
Player: A Grand Duke, you say? And what is his rescue worth to you?
Counsellor Florrick: I'll empty every last of the Council of Four's coffers, if I must. Wyll, you must hold little love for your father. But please, find him and return him to the city. Baldur's Gate needs him now, more than ever.
Wyll: Trust us to see it through, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: The Absolute's cult is based at Moonrise Towers. That's where they'll have taken the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there... ... unless darker forces are at work. This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: On my oath: I will see Duke Ravengard rescued, and his captors vanquished. I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

Player: It isn't what you think, father. It never was.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: It is exactly what I think.
Narrator: *Your head tingles. Memories flow through your mind, seeking escape.*
Player: You know nothing!
Narrator: *There is no stopping it: the truth bubbles over, flooding first your mind, then your father's.* *Ravengard sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in your face as an impossible choice is set before you.* *The past becomes present. Your father sees you partner with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll - my son. I'm so sorry. I didn't know. You sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it.
Player: I can forgive you. But I can never forget.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Nor should you. The self is the sum of its experiences. You are the man you are because of them. You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on. Waking a dragon doesn't sound like a good idea.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is no ordinary dragon. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Wyll: It's funny. As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom. I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army. But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that: Time. Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy. It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods. We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us. Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time - If just for a moment. Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn. I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough. The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave. Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else: Me. I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before - And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic. If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.

Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.

Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?

Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need. First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together. I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? My soul lies with the city. But...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But what, Wyll?
Wyll: I have slain monsters, faced illithids, guarded the helpless. To be a duke - is this the destiny I've awaited? Is the nobility my calling?

Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. These were the lessons my father taught me. Baldur's Gate is my home, and I am its servant. I will be relentless in my pursuit of the greatest good.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I would sooner die by Mizora's hand than let her endanger the city. I'll figure out a way.
Wyll: The Blade of Frontiers is no more. I will be Wyll Ravengard, son of Ulder, proud Duke of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son! Together, there is no army we cannot conquer and no wrong we cannot right. Hail Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Minsc: Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Narrator: *Wyll's courage and enthusiasm warms the air. With him at your side, the road ahead doesn't look so insurmountable.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll - he kisses back, then pulls away.
Wyll: *Sigh.* I've drunk wines from Daggerford to Cormyr, but I've never known a taste as rich as yours. Gods damn it. You almost make me forget myself. But I still keep faith in the old tales of love, the once-upon-a-times and the happily-ever-afters. I'd like to do this the proper way. The way of the old romances sung by the bards. Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

Player: I pulled you from death's grip, and this is how you thank me?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You want my gratitude? Fine - take your fill. But I will not celebrate this infernal resurrection. You turned your back on me, on your city, to chase the she-devil and her power. She stinks up this place even now.
Narrator: *Your head tingles. Memories flow through your mind, seeking escape.*
Player: I sacrificed my soul to save yours. I had no choice.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: There is always a choice.
Wyll: Father, please - there's something I must show you.
Narrator: *Ravengard's tadpole clenches as your memories - and Wyll's - flow into him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By Tyr's wounds - I'm in your mind...
Narrator: *The Grand Duke sees Mizora and her infernal sisters. He sees the agony in Wyll's face as an impossible choice is set before him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: No. My son -
Narrator: *The past becomes present, and Wyll's thoughts are laid bare. Ravengard sees Wyll partnering with Mizora to defeat Tiamat's cultists before they could lay siege to Baldur's Gate.* *And he sees everything beyond. The nautiloid journey, the perilous path to Moonrise, the Astral Prism, and the Emperor within.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.
Wyll: Everything I did, I did for Baldur's Gate. I did for you.
Player: It's the truth, Ravengard. Wyll has always been a faithful defender of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it. You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free. By the gods, can you ever forgive me?
Wyll: There's nothing to forgive. You wanted to protect the city. I only ever wanted the same.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but - - my duty is first and foremost to the city and its people. There's something I must ask of you.
Player: Go on.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Before I was captured, I was on a mission. Returning from Elturel, I discovered the plans of the Absolutists. I immediately realised the city couldn't defend itself against such an army. I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need. This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.
Player: A wyrm? Are you saying there's a dragon living under the city?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A bronze dragon, yes. He sleeps beneath us even now, awaiting a hero to rouse him. The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate. He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once. Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now. The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you. Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale. Let it set the path before you.
Player: Wyll? What do you make of this?

Player: I trust you, Wyll. Follow your heart, wherever it leads.
Wyll: I fought to right the wrongs of the Coast, to slay the men and monsters that hunt the helpless. It is in the wilds that I find my courage, not in the halls of Upper City estates. There will be no Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard. And there will be no Blade of Frontiers. I am now the Blade of Avernus. For as long as demons and devils imperil the Sword Coast, they will be my prey.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Then go with my blessing. Be Faern's great defender. Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. Let these be the lights that guide you, my son. Hail the Blade of Avernus!
Gale: The Blade of Avernus!
Narrator: *A calm settles over you. The elder brain is a menace - but with the Blade of Avernus at your side, you know you can triumph.*

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Flap those wings some more, an' I'll feed you a worm!
NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully tormenting the little kid. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.

Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Fezzerk mockingly refers to the deep gnome's predicament as he threatens the player. 'Passing by' refers to rotating on a windmill rather than safe passage through the area, in his book.

NodeContext: A dimwit bully who thinks he's shrewd operator.

Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Show him your brand and say you're taking the gnome. The Absolute wills it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Put Axe away
Fezzerk: You picked the wrong time to be cheap...
Player: Attack the goblins.

Zevlor: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Outsiders, perhaps. But not me.
Zevlor: Lucky you. There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Kirgrath: Hold up, jargh. Y-you ain't just walking away. You got Brithvar chopped - and I still haven't seen a damned coin for my trouble. You owe - what's the word? Restitution.  ([6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) That, or - or I add your corpse to the heap. Which is it?
